for a \"personal matter\", New Zealand Rugby said on Saturday just hours before the side's first Rugby Championship clash with Australia in Sydney.\n\nKaino, who has won two Rugby World Cups, had not been named in the matchday squad with Liam Squire given the starting blindside flanker role.\n\nNZR said a media report in Australia about his personal life had necessitated the 34-year-old's return to Auckland.\n\nThe world champions have been enshrouded in off-the-field controversies this week, with NZR re-opening an investigation into scrumhalf Aaron Smith's tryst with a woman, who was not his partner, in a toilet at Christchurch Airport last year.\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew said on Saturday the week had meant his organisation were under pressure.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning,\" Tew said in a statement. \"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this.\n\n\"While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters.\n\n\"We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\"\n\nThe behaviour of their players has not been the only thing distracting the team in Sydney ahead of the match, which doubles as the first of three Bledisloe Cup tests.\n\nA trial against the team's Australian security contractor also ended on Friday with Adrian Gard found not guilty of public mischief after a listening device was discovered in the team's hotel ahead of the same fixture last year.\n\nNZR were criticised last year for their handling of an investigation into the Waikato Chiefs' 'Mad Monday' celebration where the team hired an exotic dancer, who said she was touched inappropriately and had alcohol thrown at her.\n\nThe incident forced NZR to conduct a review of its culture and treatment of women. Tew said the review was expected to be made public next month.\n\n\"At a time when we are grappling with our cultural reputation, the respect and responsibility review, which is currently under way, is even more important,\" Tew said.\n\n\"The review is being presented to the NZR Board this month and we are looking to make that public sometime in September.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3373462", "id": "10014035", "url": "https://www.supersport.com//rugby/rugby-championship/news/170819/Kaino_returns_home_for_personal_reasons", "sim": 0.9647058844566345, "details": {}, "uri": "711769945", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "https://images.supersport.com/2017/8/Jerome-Kaino-161122-Arrives-G-300.jpg", "timeCrawl": "04:49:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T04:12:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Kaino returns home for 'personal' reasons", "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "id": 31}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "id": 47}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "id": 256}], "time": "04:12:00", "source": {"uri": "supersport.com", "title": "SuperSport official website", "id": "1756"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

"497781"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New Zealand Railways Department"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Railways_Department", "type": "wiki", "id": "517587"}], "body": "SYDNEY - All Blacks loose forward Jerome Kaino has returned home for a \"personal matter\", New Zealand Rugby said on Saturday just hours before the side's first Rugby Championship clash with Australia in Sydney.\n\nKaino, who has won two Rugby World Cups, had not been named in the match-day squad, with Liam Squire given the starting blindside flank role.\n\nNZR said a media report in Australia about his personal life had necessitated the 34-year-old's return to Auckland.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby (NZR) confirmed in a statement that Kaino had returned home after the Daily Telegraph newspaper in Sydney claimed Kaino was having an affair with a 24-year-old Canberra model.\n\nThe world champions have been enshrouded in off-the-field controversies this week, with NZR reopening an investigation into scrumhalf Aaron Smith's tryst with a woman, who was not his partner, in a toilet at Christchurch Airport last year.\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew said on Saturday the week had meant his organisation were under pressure.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny, and these latest stories are concerning,\" Tew said in a statement. \"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this.\n\n\"While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters.\n\n\"We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\"\n\nThe behaviour of their players has not been the only thing distracting the team in Sydney ahead of the match, which doubles as the first of three Bledisloe Cup Tests.\n\nA trial against the team's Australian security contractor also ended on Friday with Adrian Gard found not guilty of public mischief after a listening device was discovered in the team's hotel ahead of the same fixture last year.\n\nNZR were criticised last year for their handling of an investigation into the Chiefs' 'Mad Monday' celebration where the team hired an exotic dancer, who said she was touched inappropriately and had alcohol thrown at her.\n\nThe incident forced NZR to conduct a review of its culture and treatment of women. Tew said the review was expected to be made public next month.\n\n\"At a time when we are grappling with our cultural reputation, the respect and responsibility review, which is currently under way, is even more important,\" Tew said.\n\n\"The review is being presented to the NZR Board this month, and we are looking to make that public sometime in September.\"\n\nReuters, AFP", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3373462", "id": "10028084", "url": "https://www.iol.co.za/sport/rugby/rugby-championship/kaino-leaves-all-black-camp-following-affair-report-10856476", "sim": 0.9490196108818054, "details": {}, "uri": "711815502", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "https://image.iol.co.za/image/1/process/620x349?source=http://ana-baobab-prod-eu-west-2.s3.amazonaws.com/public/ana/media/media/2017/07/08/1499505208699.jpg&operation=CROP&offset=0x0&resize=2400x1344", "timeCrawl": "07:37:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T07:37:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Kaino leaves All Black camp following 'affair' report | IOL Sport", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Sydney"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "Australia"}, "type": "country"}, "type": "place"}, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "id": 47}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "id": 256}], "time": "07:37:00", "source": {"uri": "iol.co.za", "title": "IOL", "id": "1546"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

Zealand Railways Department"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Railways_Department", "type": "wiki", "id": "517587"}], "body": "All Blacks loose forward Jerome Kaino has returned home for a \"personal matter\" just hours before his side's first Rugby Championship clash with Australia in Sydney.\n\nKaino, who has won two Rugby World Cups, had not been named in the match-day squad with Liam Squire given the starting blindside flanker role.\n\nNZR said a media report in Australia about his personal life - an alleged affair with a 24-year-old former model - had necessitated the 34-year-old's return to Auckland.\n\nKaino's wife Diana wrote 'Devastated' on Facebook on Saturday morning before deleting the post.\n\nThe world champions have been enshrouded in off-the-field controversies this week, with NZR re-opening an investigation into scrum-half Aaron Smith's tryst with a woman, who was not his partner, in a toilet at Christchurch Airport last year.\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew has admitted these controversies have put his organisation under pressure.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning,\" Tew said in a statement. \"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this.\n\n\"While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters.\n\n\"We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\"\n\nThe behaviour of their players has not been the only thing distracting the team in Sydney ahead of the match, which doubles as the first of three Bledisloe Cup Tests.\n\nA trial against the team's Australian security contractor also ended on Friday with Adrian Gard found not guilty of public mischief after a listening device was discovered in the team's hotel ahead of the same fixture last year.\n\nNZR were criticised last year for their handling of an investigation into the Waikato Chiefs' 'Mad Monday' celebration where the team hired an exotic dancer, who said she was touched inappropriately and had alcohol thrown at her.\n\nThe incident forced NZR to conduct a review of its culture and treatment of women. Tew said the review was expected to be made public next month.\n\n\"At a time when we are grappling with our cultural reputation, the respect and responsibility review, which is currently under way, is even more important,\" Tew said.\n\n\"The review is being presented to the NZR Board this month and we are looking to make that public sometime in September.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3373462", "id": "10029962", "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/rugby-union/2017/08/19/blacks-rocked-second-scandal-jerome-kaino-forced-leave-squad/", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "details": {}, "uri": "711820819", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/content/dam/rugby-union/2017/08/19/TELEMMGLPICT000133228806-xlarge_trans_NvBQzQNjv4Bq90JsMauqkzRhOnTEP_rlOmA5ZfqHzkDroTWeCKP4q90.jpeg", "timeCrawl": "08:02:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T08:02:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "All Blacks rocked by second scandal as Jerome Kaino forced to leave squad amid further Aaron Smith fall-out", "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "id": 47}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "id": 256}], "time": "08:02:00", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "title": "The Telegraph", "id": "220"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

"body": "Kaino, who has won two Rugby World Cups, had not been named in the matchday squad with Liam Squire given the starting blindside flanker role.\n\nNZR said a media report in Australia about his scrumhalf Aaron Smith's tryst with a woman, who was not his partner, in a toilet at Christchurch Airport last year.\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew said on Saturday the week had meant his organisation were under pressure.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning,\" Tew said in a statement. \"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this.\n\n\"While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters.\n\n\"We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\"\n\nThe behaviour of their players has not been the only thing distracting the team in Sydney ahead of the match, which doubles as the first of three Bledisloe Cup tests.\n\nA trial against the team's Australian security contractor also ended on Friday with Adrian Gard found not guilty of public mischief after a listening device was discovered in the team's hotel ahead of the same fixture last year.\n\nNZR were criticised last year for their handling of an investigation into the Waikato Chiefs' 'Mad Monday' celebration where the team hired an exotic dancer, who said she was touched inappropriately and had alcohol thrown at her.\n\nThe incident forced NZR to conduct a review of its culture and treatment of women. his first international try and South Africa claimed a 37-15 victory over Argentina in their Rugby Championship opener on Saturday.\n\nThe Springboks dominated the physical contest and scored tries through winger Courtnall Skosan, flanker Siya Kolisi and lock Pieter-Steph du Toit, their fourth victory in a row after a 3-0 clean-sweep of France.\n\nArgentina defended manfully and enjoyed little demolished the Wallabies 54-34.\n\nThe world champions have been enshrouded in off-the-field controversies this week, with NZR re-opening an investigation into scrumhalf Aaron Smith's tryst with a woman, who was not his partner, in a toilet at Christchurch Airport last year.\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew said on Saturday the week had meant his organisation were under pressure.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning,\" Tew said in a statement. \"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this.\n\n\"While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters.\n\n\"We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\"\n\nThe behaviour of their players has not been the only thing distracting the team.\n\nA trial against their Australian security contractor also ended on Friday with Adrian Gard found not guilty of public mischief after a listening device was discovered in the team's hotel ahead of the same fixture last year.\n\nNZR were criticised last year for their handling of an investigation into the Waikato Chiefs' 'Mad Monday' celebration where the team hired an exotic dancer, who said she was touched inappropriately and had alcohol thrown at her.\n\nThe incident forced NZR to conduct a review of its culture and treatment of women. "Mart\u00edn Landajo"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mart\u00edn_Landajo", "type": "wiki", "id": "1272384"}], "body": "South Africa's class has shown through in their Rugby Championship opener, running out to a 37-15 win over Argentina in Port Elizabeth.\n\nGhana-born winger Raymond Rhule scored his first international try as South Africa claimed a 37-15 victory over Argentina in their Rugby Championship opener.\n\nThe Springboks dominated the physical contest and scored tries through winger Courtnall Skosan, flanker Siya Kolisi and lock Pieter-Steph du Toit, their fourth victory in a row after a 3-0 clean-sweep of France.\n\nArgentina defended manfully and enjoyed little possession, but managed tries through experienced halfback Martin Landajo and winger Emiliano Boffelli.\n\nThe Springboks also handed a first cap to 20-year-old five-eighth Curwin Bosch when he replaced Elton Jantjies late in the game.\n\n\"We couldn't have asked for a better start (to the competition),\" captain Eben Etzebeth said.\n\n\"We said at halftime we must keep going and the ball will break for us.\"\n\nAfter a miserable 2016 in which they lost eight of their 12 Tests, signs of a Bok revival continued as they won key battles against the Argentines.\n\nThe home side were dominant in the scrum and held their defensive shape well, offering little space for the visitors to exploit.\n\nSouth Africa dominated possession in the opening half but, after Jantjies had kicked two penalties, it was the visitors who scored the opening try against the run of play. They completed a swift break in the corner after Jan Serfontein's attempted grubber kick was scooped up and Landajo was sent clear to dot down.\n\nBut a moment of magic by Skosan just before halftime, coupled with some weak defence, allowed the wing erto score his maiden international try as the Springboks headed into the break with a 13-5 advantage.\n\nThe teams traded penalties early in the second period, before the Boks took control of the game when Rhule rounded off some slick handling to cross for his try.\n\nAt that stage South Africa led by 15 points, but that was cut to seven when Boffelli crossed in the corner for the visitors after some concerted pressure in the home 22.\n\nWith 20 minutes to go the game was still in the balance, though the Boks continued to dominate possession and territory, and they made sure of the win as Kolisi and Du Toit crossed for tries against the wilting Argentine defence.\n\n\"South Africa had a great game,\" said Landajo. \"We need to improve at the breakdown, the ball was very slow. Next week in Salta we will try to use our home crowd to our advantage.\"\n\nArgentina will host the Boks in Salta next Saturday.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3374439", "id": "10097319", "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/20/springboks-down-pumas-physical-clash", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "details": {}, "uri": "712006762", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/sites/sbs.com.au.news/files/styles/full/public/images/r/u/RU_SAfrica_4-3_12522936_1762407_59988773ca6a936ba4d508c1_sd_800x600.jpg?itok=Gfj2jsdr", "timeCrawl": "18:58:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:58:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Springboks down Pumas in physical clash", "location": null, "categories": [], "time": "18:58:00", "source": {"uri": "sbs.com.au", "title": "SBS", "id": "793"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

"Curtis Rona"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_Rona", "type": "person", "id": "452536"}], "body": "An increasingly acrimonious rivalry between the All Blacks and Wallabies has become more pronounced ahead of their first test of the Rugby Championship on Saturday.\n\nA sex scandal involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper on the eve of the Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, and a Sydney court is hearing a case concerning the discovery of a listening device in the All Blacks' hotel before a match in Sydney last season.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby has moved quickly to try to shut down the Smith scandal by appointing an independent lawyer to review its handling of the matter when it first arose last year.\n\nThe bugging controversy is more complicated and has done more than anything else to sour relations between the Australian and New Zealand teams.\n\nIn the week before last year's Bledisloe Cup test, the All Blacks claimed to have found a listening device embedded in a chair in their team room at a Sydney Hotel: the room in which tactics are often discussed.\n\nThe discovery was made by an Australian security contractor, Adrian Gard, who had worked with the All Blacks team for more than a decade.\n\nThe All Blacks informed hotel management early in the week, but opted against calling in police until the morning of the match -- when the story was reported by a New Zealand newspaper.\n\nThe Australian Rugby Union was angry the All Blacks kept silent on the incident for so long and suspected they leaked it to media for a match day distraction.\n\nAustralia coach Michael Cheika was more incensed, thinking the All Blacks had implied the Wallabies were in some way responsible.\n\n\"They had that the whole week. That showed a lack of respect,\" Cheika said. \"I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organized. I am too busy working on my own thing.\"\n\nCheika has had a frosty relationship with his All Blacks counterpart Steve Hansen as he maintains his conviction that the bugging plot was hatched to discredit the Wallabies.\n\nGard has pleaded not guilty to a charge of public mischief, with police alleging he made a false claim regarding the bug.\n\nHansen is adamant the All Blacks have never implied the Wallabies were involved in the bugging incident.\n\n\"I don't know where they feel the inference was,\" Hansen said. \"We don't know who put it there. I said that at the time and that hasn't changed.\"\n\nThe Smith controversy has also intruded into the All Blacks' match preparation.\n\nA newspaper quoted a woman who had a sexual encounter with Smith at Dunedin Airport last September as saying Smith encouraged her to lie about the incident.\n\nSmith was suspended for a week after being sent home before a test match in South Africa but the newspaper alleges New Zealand Rugby didn't have the full facts when it levied punishment. New Zealand Rugby has opened a fresh inquiry to consider the new evidence.\n\nAt his news conference Thursday, Hansen raised the Smith issue before reporters asked.\n\n\"Obviously the incident happened last year. We dealt with it and we feel that we dealt with it decisively,\" Hansen said. \"There's nothing more that I can add to that but if there is anything else that needs to be spoken about, it will come from the New Zealand Rugby Union.\"\n\nThe issues swirling about the All Blacks might help decrease pressure on the Wallabies at a time of turmoil in Australian rugby. The poor performance of Australia's Super Rugby teams and the failure of the Australian Rugby Union in the process of cutting one of those teams next season has damaged the sport.\n\nA heavy loss by the Wallabies might compound those problems but Cheika has been able to prepare his players in relative quiet while the All Blacks have had to deal with off-field issues.\n\nCheika was able to name his team without undue scrutiny of his decision to include on one wing Curtis Rona -- a rugby league convert who has played 80 minutes at winger in his short rugby union career. The All Blacks team announcement, which could have concentrated on a reorganized back three and the dropping of veteran flanker Jerome Kaino, instead was overshadowed by Smith and bugging.\n\nAP Sports Writer Steve McMorran contributed from Wellington, New Zealand\n\n\u00a9 Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Rugby_Union", "type": "wiki", "id": "407266"}], "body": "SYDNEY (AP) - An increasingly acrimonious rivalry between the All Blacks and Wallabies has become more pronounced ahead of their first test of the Rugby Championship on Saturday.\n\nA sex scandal involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper on the eve of the Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, and a Sydney court is hearing a case concerning the discovery of a listening device in the All Blacks' hotel before a match in Sydney last season.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby has moved quickly to try to shut down the Smith scandal by appointing an independent lawyer to review its handling of the matter when it first arose last year.\n\nFILE - In this file photo dated Saturday, July 1, 2017, New Zealand center Sonny Bill Williams walks from the field after he was sent off during the second rugby test between the British and Irish Lions and the All Blacks in Wellington, New Zealand. Williams has been recalled to the All Blacks team, it is announced Wednesday Aug. 16, 2017, for upcoming Saturday's Rugby Championship and Bledisloe Cup test against Australia after completing a four-match suspension following his sending off against the British and Irish Lions.(AP Photo/Mark Baker, FILE)\n\nThe bugging controversy is more complicated and has done more than anything else to sour relations between the Australian and New Zealand teams.\n\nIn the week before last year's Bledisloe Cup test, the All Blacks claimed to have found a listening device embedded in a chair in their team room at a Sydney Hotel: the room in which tactics are often discussed.\n\nThe discovery was made by an Australian security contractor, Adrian Gard, who had worked with the All Blacks team for more than a decade.\n\nThe All Blacks informed hotel management early in the week, but opted against calling in police until the morning of the match - when the story was reported by a New Zealand newspaper.\n\nThe Australian Rugby Union was angry the All Blacks kept silent on the incident for so long and suspected they leaked it to media for a match day distraction.\n\nAustralia coach Michael Cheika was more incensed, thinking the All Blacks had implied the Wallabies were in some way responsible.\n\n\"They had that the whole week. That showed a lack of respect,\" Cheika said. \"I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organized. I am too busy working on my own thing.\"\n\nCheika has had a frosty relationship with his All Blacks counterpart Steve Hansen as he maintains his conviction that the bugging plot was hatched to discredit the Wallabies.\n\nGard has pleaded not guilty to a charge of public mischief, with police alleging he made a false claim regarding the bug.\n\nHansen is adamant the All Blacks have never implied the Wallabies were involved in the bugging incident.\n\n\"I don't know where they feel the inference was,\" Hansen said. \"We don't know who put it there. I said that at the time and that hasn't changed.\"\n\nThe Smith controversy has also intruded into the All Blacks' match preparation.\n\nA newspaper quoted a woman who had a sexual encounter with Smith at Dunedin Airport last September as saying Smith encouraged her to lie about the incident.\n\nSmith was suspended for a week after being sent home before a test match in South Africa but the newspaper alleges New Zealand Rugby didn't have the full facts when it levied punishment. New Zealand Rugby has opened a fresh inquiry to consider the new evidence.\n\nAt his news conference Thursday, Hansen raised the Smith issue before reporters asked.\n\n\"Obviously the incident happened last year. We dealt with it and we feel that we dealt with it decisively,\" Hansen said. \"There's nothing more that I can add to that but if there is anything else that needs to be spoken about, it will come from the New Zealand Rugby Union.\"\n\nThe issues swirling about the All Blacks might help decrease pressure on the Wallabies at a time of turmoil in Australian rugby. The poor performance of Australia's Super Rugby teams and the failure of the Australian Rugby Union in the process of cutting one of those teams next season has damaged the sport.\n\nA heavy loss by the Wallabies might compound those problems but Cheika has been able to prepare his players in relative quiet while the All Blacks have had to deal with off-field issues.\n\nCheika was able to name his team without undue scrutiny of his decision to include on one wing Curtis Rona - a rugby league convert who has played 80 minutes at winger in his short rugby union career. The All Blacks team announcement, which could have concentrated on a reorganized back three and the dropping of veteran flanker Jerome Kaino, instead was overshadowed by Smith and bugging.\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Steve McMorran contributed from Wellington, New Zealand", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "9816307", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801392/index.html", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "details": {}, "uri": "711229413", "extractedDates": [{"date": "2017-07-01", "textStart": 712, "textEnd": 724, "amb": false}, {"date": "2017-08-16", "textStart": 997, "textEnd": 1010, "amb": false}], "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/1/2017/08/18/04/wire-1157001-1503026230-884_636x382.jpg", "timeCrawl": "03:35:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:35:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "All Blacks, Wallabies take rivalry off field before 1st test", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Sydney"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "Australia"}, "type": "country"}, "type": "place"}, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "id": 31}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "id": 47}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "id": 757}], "time": "03:35:00", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "date": "2017-08-18", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18"}

"label": {"eng": "Eben Etzebeth"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eben_Etzebeth", "type": "person", "id": "468552"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Siya Kolisi"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siya_Kolisi", "type": "person", "id": "533918"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Jan Serfontein"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Serfontein", "type": "person", "id": "533919"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Mart\u00edn Landajo"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mart\u00edn_Landajo", "type": "wiki", "id": "1272384"}], "body": "Ghana-born wing Raymond Rhule scored his first international try as South Africa claimed victory over Argentina in their Rugby Championship opener on Saturday.\n\nThe Springboks dominated the physical contest and scored tries through winger Courtnall Skosan, flanker Siya Kolisi and lock Pieter-Steph du Toit, their fourth victory in a row after a 3-0 clean-sweep of France.\n\nArgentina defended manfully and enjoyed little possession, but managed tries through experienced scrumhalf Martin Landajo and winger Emiliano Boffelli.\n\nThe Springboks also handed a first cap to 20-year-old outhalf Curwin Bosch when he replaced Elton Jantjies late in the game.\n\n\"We couldn?t have asked for a better start (to the competition),\" Bok captain Eben Etzebeth said after the game.\n\n\"We said at half-time we must keep going and the ball will break for us.\"\n\nAfter a miserable 2016 in which they lost eight of their 12 tests, signs of a Bok revival continued as they won key battles against Argentina.\n\nThe home side were dominant in the scrum and held their defensive shape well, offering little space for the visitors to exploit.\n\nThe Boks dominated possession in the opening half, but after Jantjies had kicked two penalties, it was the visitors who scored the opening try against the run of play. They completed a swift break in the corner after Jan Serfontein's attempted grubber kick was scooped up and Landajo was sent clear to dot down.\n\nBut a moment of magic by Skosan just before half-time, coupled with some weak Argentine defence, allowed the wing to score his maiden international try as the Boks headed into the break with a 13-5 advantage.\n\nThe teams traded penalties early in the second period, before the Boks took control of the game when Rhule rounded off some slick handling to cross for his try.\n\nAt that stage the Boks led by 15 points, but that was cut to seven when Boffelli crossed in the corner for the visitors after some concerted pressure in the home 22.\n\nWith 20 minutes to go the game was still in the balance, though the Boks continued to dominate possession and territory, and they made sure of the win as Kolisi and Du Toit crossed for tries against the wilting Argentine defence.\n\n\"South Africa had a great game,\" said Landajo. \"We need to improve at the breakdown, the ball was very slow. "72814", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Christchurch"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "New Zealand"}, "type": "country"}, "type": "place"}}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Misogyny"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team", "type": "wiki", "id": "346371"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jerome Kaino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Kaino", "type": "person", "id": "434172"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Steve Tew"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Tew", "type": "person", "id": "497781"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New Zealand Railways Department"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Railways_Department", "type": "wiki", "id": "517587"}], "body": "New Zealand's top players may be struggling to learn from off field mistakes but at least the administration of the sport has shown in the last week that it has taken on board the need to react to scandals quickly, decisively and boldly.\n\nWithin hours of the Aaron Smith saga erupting again this week, New Zealand Rugby had a statement out that they were re-opening the investigation and doing so with an independent lawyer at the helm.\n\nWithin hours of Jerome Kaino boarding a flight home after a story appeared in the Australian media claiming he had an extra marital affair, NZR was again quick to condemn the behaviour and point out that while it was a personal matter, the impact to the reputational damage to the All Blacks and the sport would be significant.\n\nCompare this with last year when the same body took five days to report the discovery of a listening device in their team hotel to the New South Wales Police.\n\nMuch worse was the ineffective response to what seemed like the never ending Chiefs stripper scandal and then there were concerns about how long it took NZR to get a handle on the issue involving Wellington player Losi Filipo who was discharged without conviction in an assault case that involved two women.\n\nIt was a horrible year for NZR and rugby in general as these various scandals and the ineffective handling of them, opened the game to accusations it was nurturing a misogynistic culture and failing to embrace any kind of diversity.\n\nIt was a particularly difficult year for chief executive Steve Tew, who became the target of the public and media ire at the continued botched handling of the various scandals.\n\nHe reached the end of 2016 acutely aware of his need, as the head of the organisation, to be delivering more powerful statements of condemnation and more decisive action plans to discipline those individuals who fail to uphold the expected standards of morality and conduct.\n\nAs much as anything, what Tew learned the hard way is that all roads lead back to him in the sense that both the public and media have an expectation that he should take responsibility to deal with all matters rugby almost regardless of whom they involve.\n\nThe other significant lesson NZR had to absorb is that if nothing else, they need to at least be seen to be taking matters involving off field conduct ultra seriously.\n\nAnd it's that lesson especially which has driven much of the governing body's response this last week.\n\nWhen the statement was released on Thursday that the Smith investigation was being re-opened, NZR probably felt another probe would be unlikely to find much, if any new evidence that would be a concern to them.\n\nBut still, they knew it was better to be sure on that front and to hand responsibility for that process to a genuinely independent person.\n\nThat was one of the mistakes they made with the Chiefs investigation last year - it wasn't deemed to have been conducted by an independent source and therefore the findings were easy to shoot down and dismiss as credible.\n\nAnd if the investigation was initially re-opened more for appearances sake, that will no longer be the case given the information that has come to light in the Herald, with allegations that Smith was involved with another woman after he was disciplined for his infamous toilet tryst in Christchurch.\n\nAgain, while the situation with Kaino - a high profile, senior leader within the All Blacks - is not one that is enhancing of the standing or reputation of the national team, NZR has at least shut the door on the organisation being open to accusations it hasn't taken the matter seriously.\n\nKaino's alleged conduct, while lacking in personal value, wouldn't, if it is true, constitute a breach of either team protocol and certainly doesn't come under any scrutiny as an employment issue.\n\nNZR, could, therefore, have ignored the matter entirely on the basis that what Kaino does in his private life in his private time is his business.\n\nBut the lessons of last year have been learned and such a stance would have been naive. Kaino asking to come home on the morning of a major test is clearly a major story and everyone knows why he has asked to do that.\n\nThe reputational damage to the All Blacks brand - particularity given the situation with Smith - will be compounded and NZR has learned that saying nothing is not an option.\n\nInstead, a strong statement was issued by Tew that doesn't suggest the game is not without its problems, but it does at least provide some reassurance that the people asked to deal with these issues, are trying to do so.\n\n\"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning,\" said Tew.\n\n\"As an employer, we will take some time to assess this. While NZR does not wish to comment on individual behaviour, it is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and supporters. We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\n\n\"At a time when we are grappling with our cultural reputation, the Respect and Responsibility Review, which is currently under way, is even more important. The review is being presented to the NZR board this month and we are looking to make that public sometime in September.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3373462", "id": "10022795", "url": "http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=11907326", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "details": {}, "uri": "711797498", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://www.nzherald.co.nz/resizer/He2mC3geJ84dUjk-EFhCJrcj47w=/1200x0/smart/filters:quality(70)/arc-anglerfish-syd-prod-nzme.s3.amazonaws.com/public/Z2RQVNFOUVDYXLC5YQYDUSO4BQ.jpg", "timeCrawl": "06:26:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T06:26:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Gregor Paul: New Zealand Rugby responding well to All Blacks' issues", "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "id": 41}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "id": 107}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "id": 268}], "time": "06:26:00", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "title": "The New Zealand Herald", "id": "1424"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

Force funds to support women's rugby, grassroots\n\nCameron Clyne asks the Force who should suffer instead?\n\nUp Next ARU cuts Force ARU cuts Force ARU cuts Force\n\nARU chairman Cameron Clyne blames performance for the code's financial stress in Australia.\n\nUp Next Hooper steps up as Wallabies skipper Hooper steps up as Wallabies skipper Hooper steps up as Wallabies skipper\n\nMichael Hooper has been appointed Wallabies captain, with long-serving Stephen Moore stepping down from the role ahead of his international retirement at the end of the season.\n\nMore videos All Blacks school Wallabies in opening Bledisloe\n\nA near perfect first half from the All Blacks left the Wallabies attempting to claw back some respectability in the opening game of the Rugby Championship.\n\nIt was the second-most points the Wallabies have ever conceded and the third time in five years the All Blacks have piled on 40 points in a Bledisloe Cup opener in Sydney.\n\n\"Defence has been an issue,\" quipped Wallabies coach Michael Cheika at half-time in what was one of the understatements of the year.\n\nRelated Articles All Blacks star Kaino returns home for 'personal' reasons Hooper daring to dream of Bledisloe upset\n\nWhen Australia trailed 40-6 at the main break, there was little new skipper Michael Hooper could have said to his distraught troops in what has to be one of the most brutal introductions to full-time Wallabies captaincy.\n\nAt one stage the Wallabies were trailing 54-6 after 48 minutes and staring down the barrel of their worst defeat but four tries in 17 minutes - from Curtis Rona, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau - saved them plenty of embarrassment.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFor context, the Wallabies missed a staggering 40 per cent (37 from 94) of all tackles in the first half and there will be immense pressure on defence coach Nathan Grey given what the Waratahs dished up this year too.\n\nBy the end of 80 minutes, Australia had missed 48 tackles, which is just not good enough at international level.\n\nIn last year's bloodbath against New Zealand in Sydney, the full-time margin was 34 points. On Saturday, the All Blacks led by that buffer at half-time.\n\nNew Zealand piled on an incredible six tries in the first half, which was more than they scored in the entire series against the British and Irish Lions.\n\nAnd when the All Blacks chalked up their eighth try in the 48th minute, thanks to a sensational pass back inside to Ben Smith from Aaron Smith, it marked the most points they had ever scored against Australia, from 182 matches.\n\nCheika may have boasted the Wallabies were fit and raring to go but they sure as anything didn't do enough work on their defensive structures in an abysmal effort.\n\nMeanwhile, after one of the most tumultuous weeks for New Zealand rugby in recent memory, the All Blacks were able to push to one side the off-field scandals and execute a game plan that completely blew the Wallabies off the park.\n\nHalfback Aaron Smith, whose \"toilet tryst\" last year resurfaced during the week as did fresh allegations of affairs with other women, had a brilliant game and was clearly unperturbed by what had transpired in recent days.\n\nCoach Steve Hansen's mind, however, would have been in two places hours before kick-off after it emerged New Zealand's team manager Darren Shand told police he believed Cheika was responsible for bugging the team's hotel last year.\n\nThe All Blacks, however, were more than able to separate on-field from off-field but will be annoyed they did not completely put Australia to the sword in the second half.\n\nTo the surprise of many, it was the Wallabies who got on the scoresheet first thanks to a penalty after four minutes to Bernard Foley on the back of some excellent attacking bursts in the All Blacks' 22.\n\nBut like they do so often, the All Blacks capitalised on a mistake from their opposition.\n\nAllan Alaalatoa knocked the ball on and shortly afterwards New Zealand were able to get auspicious front-foot ball before Liam Squire, Jerome Kaino's replacement, scored down the left edge.\n\nA Wallabies penalty brought the margin back to one point but that's about as good as it got for Cheika's men before a poor defensive read from Folau on the right edge saw Rieko Ioane put the visitors ahead 12-6.\n\nThe All Blacks, through Ioane and Ryan Crotty, then scored two tries in four minutes to put their tally at 26 points in as many minutes to silence a crowd of 54,846 at ANZ Stadium.\n\nAustralia's defensive line looked scrambled and they were unable to adapt on the run to countless questions asked by New Zealand's backs.\n\nRona scored a try on debut in the 52nd minute and when Kuridrani squeezed through a gap to go over the line in the 56th minute, Australia looked a completely different outfit.\n\nAttack-wise, there were things to like. Beale brought the flair we expected and scored Australia's third consecutive try when he scooped up a loose ball and ran 50 metres.\n\nThe 34 points the Wallabies racked up was actually the second-most against the All Blacks.\n\nThe bad news? Sydney on Saturday.\n\nIt was New Zealand's biggest score over Australia, eclipsing their 51-20 win in Auckland three years ago and puts them well on he way to holding on to the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup, which they have held since 2003.\n\nNew Zealand's inability to put away the British and Irish Lions in their drawn home series last month had raised doubts whether the All Blacks' era of dominance was on the wane.\n\nBut the All Blacks roared back to outclass the Australians eight tries to four in a dynamic performance.\n\nWhile the Wallabies added some respectability to the final score after trailing 54-6 with four tries in the final half-hour the contest was well and truly over after the first 50 minutes.\n\nWhile it was a dominant Test for the All Blacks it plunged Australia rugby further in the gloom after a woeful Super Rugby season where Australian teams lost all their 26 games to New Zealand opposition.\n\nIt was played before the lowest Bledisloe Cup Test crowd at Sydney's Olympic stadium of 54,846.\n\nThe All Blacks demoralised the tackle-shy Wallabies with a six-try opening half to have the game wrapped up by half-time after a 40-6 landslide.\n\nWhile the Australians looked promising in attack they were clueless in defence with the world champions looking capable of scoring in every attacking phase.\n\nThe Wallabies left the field to stunned silence with their already tenuous Bledisloe Cup hopes in tatters with the All Blacks at home in the potentially deciding game in Dunedin next week.\n\nThe All Blacks scored their first try with quick passes from skipper Kieran Read and winger Rieko Ioane to give blindside flanker Liam Squire a clear run to the try-line.\n\nBernard Foley kicked the Wallabies to trail by a point with a 17th-minute penalty after the All Blacks scrum was penalised.\n\nBut the All Blacks again found a way through the Australian defence when left-winger Ioane got on the outside of floundering Israel Folau to score for a 12-6 lead midway through the half.\n\nIoane was over again minutes later when Michael Hooper's pass went astray and Ryan Crotty sent Ioane racing away between the posts.\n\n- Defence shredded -\n\nThe Wallabies defence was shredded again and Crotty scored an easy try near the posts after Beauden Barrett handled twice in the lead-up.\n\nThe New Zealanders claimed their fifth try just before half-time when Sonny Bill Williams crashed over and Barrett's conversion stretched the world champions' lead to 33-6.\n\nThe All Blacks made a mockery of the threadbare Australian defence with a sixth try off a training ground move and a double to centre Crotty after a scrum win deep inside the Wallabies' territory.\n\nBarrett's conversion gave the All Blacks an impregnable 40-6 lead at half-time.\n\nIt got no better with fullback Damian McKenzie scoring his first Test try three minutes after the resumption and Barrett's sixth conversion extended the lead to 47-6.\n\nWinger Ben Smith's try hoisted the All Blacks to their highest ever score against the Wallabies 54-6 and with still 30 minutes left in the one-sided Test.\n\nDebutant winger Curtis Rona finally scored Australia's first try after 52 minutes and further tries to replacement Tevita Kuridrani and a runaway from Kurtley Beale gave the home supporters something to cheer.\n\nIsrael Folau crossed for Australia's fourth try 11 minutes from the end.\n\nThe All Blacks continued their domination of the Wallabies and have lost only three of their last 30 encounters.", "originalArticle": null, with All Blacks teammate Rieko Ioane. (Credit: AAP)\n\nIf Australian rugby fans needed any further reminding of the poor state of the game in this country it was provided by the All Blacks, who destroyed the Wallabies 54-34 in their Bledisloe Cup encounter in Sydney.\n\nThe final scoreline flattered the Wallabies, who were outclassed at the Olympic stadium by the All Blacks, with the world champions taking their foot off the pedal after they led 54-6 early in the second half.\n\nIt was the most points the All Blacks had ever scored against the Wallabies, who eventually grabbed some consolation tries through debutant Curtis Rona, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau.\n\nThe night belonged to the All Blacks, who issued a statement of how far ahead they are of their trans-Tasman rivals despite going through the motions for much of the second half.\n\nAustralia's provincial teams could not muster a win against their New Zealand counterparts during the Super Rugby season, an embarrassing statistic which was reflected in the All Blacks' dominance of the Wallabies on Saturday night.\n\nThe two sides will meet in the second Bledisloe Cup Test in Dunedin next Saturday.\n\n\"It is not the start we would have hoped for,\" Wallabies captain Michael Hooper said.\n\n\"Being 50 points behind, you start to throw everything we had, I'm so happy with that.\"\n\nThe All Blacks scored eight tries in total, six of which came in the first half with Rieko Ioane and Ryan Crotty both registering doubles before the break.\n\nThe contest was already over at half-time when the All Blacks led 40-6 and they moved further ahead inside eight minutes of the resumption of play courtesy of tries to Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith.\n\n\"It was pretty surreal that first half to be honest,\" All Blacks captain Kieran Read said.\n\n\"We came here to play our game and it really came off. It was a pretty awesome first half. It came about by the doing the simple things.\n\n\"We carried really hard and exploited a few gaps out wide.\"\n\nA crowd of just 54,846 spectators, the lowest ever for a Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, were witnessing one of the Wallabies' worst performances before Rona finally scored the home side's first try in the 51st minute.\n\nKuridrani, Beale and Folau followed with their efforts across the stripe but it was clear the All Blacks had shut down, perhaps with thoughts already turning to the Dunedin encounter in a week's time.\n\nIf history is any guide, the Bledisloe Cup will remain in New Zealand hands for a 15th straight year with the Wallabies having never won a series after losing the first match at home.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "Shares\n\nNew Zealand's winger Rieko Ioane scores a try during the Rugby Championship victory over Australia in Sydney, on August 19, 2017 \u00a9 AFP / SAEED KHAN\n\nSYDNEY, Australia, Aug 19 - The world champion All Blacks rebounded spectacularly to down the Wallabies 54-34 and plunge Australian rugby further into despair in the Rugby Championship opener in Sydney on Saturday.\n\nIt was New Zealand's biggest score over Australia, eclipsing their 51-20 win in Auckland three years ago and puts them well on he way to holding on to the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup, which they have held since 2003.\n\nNew Zealand's inability to put away the British and Irish Lions in their drawn home series last month had raised doubts whether the All Blacks' era of dominance was on the wane.\n\nBut the All Blacks roared back to outclass the Australians eight tries to four in a dynamic performance.\n\nWhile the Wallabies added some respectability to the final score after trailing 54-6 with four tries in the final half-hour the contest was well and truly over after the first 50 minutes.\n\nWhile it was a dominant Test for the All Blacks it plunged Australia rugby further in the gloom after a woeful Super Rugby season where Australian teams lost all their 26 games to New Zealand opposition.\n\nIt was played before the lowest Bledisloe Cup Test crowd at Sydney's Olympic stadium of 54,846.\n\nThe All Blacks demoralised the tackle-shy Wallabies with a six-try opening half to have the game wrapped up by half-time after a 40-6 landslide.\n\nWhile the Australians looked promising in attack they were clueless in defence with the world champions looking capable of scoring in every attacking phase.\n\nThe Wallabies left the field to stunned silence with their already tenuous Bledisloe Cup hopes in tatters with the All Blacks at home in the potentially deciding game in Dunedin next week.\n\nThe All Blacks scored their first try with quick passes from skipper Kieran Read and winger Rieko Ioane to give blindside flanker Liam Squire a clear run to the try-line.\n\nBernard Foley kicked the Wallabies to trail by a point with a 17th-minute penalty after the All Blacks scrum was penalised.\n\nBut the All Blacks again found a way through the Australian defence when left-winger Ioane got on the outside of floundering Israel Folau to score for a 12-6 lead midway through the half.\n\nIoane was over again minutes later when Michael Hooper's pass went astray and Ryan Crotty sent Ioane racing away between the posts.\n\n- Defence shredded -\n\nAustralia's fullback Israel Folau scores a try during the Rugby Championship match against the New Zealand All Blacks in Sydney, on the threadbare Australian defence with a sixth try off a training ground move and a double to centre Crotty after a scrum win deep inside the Wallabies' territory.\n\nBarrett's conversion gave the All Blacks an impregnable 40-6 lead at half-time.\n\nIt got no better with fullback Damian McKenzie scoring his first Test try three minutes after the resumption and Barrett's sixth conversion extended continue the gloom in Australian rugby in their Rugby Championship opener in Sydney on Saturday.\n\nIt was New Zealand's biggest score over Australia, eclipsing their 51-20 win in Auckland three years ago.\n\nWhile the Wallabies added some respectability to the score after trailing 54-6 with four tries in the final half-hour, the contest was finished after the first 50 minutes.\n\n\"The first 50 minutes was probably as good rugby as you will see, the last 30 minutes was probably some of the ugliest rugby,\" All Blacks coach Steve Hansen said.\n\n\"I think we got a little seduced by the scoreboard and went away from the fundamentals of what we wanted to do, but I think it's about concentrating on what we did really well and that first 50 minutes was pretty special.\"\n\nNew Zealand's inability to put away the British and Irish Lions in their drawn home series last month had raised doubts over the All Blacks' era of dominance.\n\nBut they roared back in their inimitable fashion, posting an eight tries to four victory.\n\nWhile the All Blacks stamped their mark early on the Test match it was another blow to Australian rugby following a woeful Super Rugby season, where Australian teams lost all their 26 games to New Zealand opposition.\n\nAnother low was that the game was played before the smallest Bledisloe Cup Test crowd at Sydney's Olympic stadium of 54,846.\n\n\"It was pretty plain to see that our defence wasn't good enough at all,\" Wallabies coach Michael Cheika told reporters.\n\n\"The adherence to the way we wanted to defend plus the tackling in itself has got to be better. That first part of the game is not at the level that you can be at all.\"\n\nThe All Blacks demoralised the tackle-shy Wallabies with a six-try opening half blitz to have the game wrapped up by half-time after a 40-6 landslide.\n\nThey extended that to 54-6 after 48 minutes before the Australians scored four tries of their own to remove the threat of their heaviest losing margin of 37 points (43-6) against New Zealand in 1996.\n\nThe All Blacks look set to retain the Bledisloe Cup for a 15th consecutive year in Dunedin next weekend.\n\n- Threadbare defence -\n\nBlindside flanker Liam Squire scored New Zealand's first try in the 10th minute and went in again when left-winger Rieko Ioane got on the outside of floundering Israel Folau to score.\n\nIoane was over again minutes later sixth try off a rehearsed training ground move for centre Crotty's try double off a scrum win deep inside Wallabies' territory.\n\nBarrett's conversion gave the All Blacks an unassailable lead at half-time.\n\nIt got no better with fullback Damian McKenzie scoring his first Test try three minutes after the resumption, and winger Ben Smith's try hoisted the All Blacks to their highest ever score against the Wallabies with still 30 minutes left in an embarrassingly one-sided Test.\n\nDebutant winger Curtis Rona finally crossed for Australia's first try after 52 minutes and further tries "id": "1272251"}], "body": "SYDNEY - The world champion All Blacks rebounded spectacularly to down the Wallabies 54-34 and plunge Australian rugby further into despair in the Rugby Championship opener in Sydney on Saturday.\n\nIt was New Zealand's biggest score over Australia, eclipsing their 51-20 win in Auckland three years ago and puts them well on the way to holding on to the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup, which they have held since 2003.\n\nNew Zealand's inability to put away the British and Irish Lions in their drawn home series last month had raised doubts whether the All Blacks' era of dominance was on the wane.\n\nBut the All Blacks roared back to outclass the Australians eight tries to four in a dynamic performance.\n\nWhile the Wallabies added some respectability to the final score after trailing 54-6 with four tries in the final half-hour the contest was well and truly over after the first 50 minutes.\n\nWhile it was a dominant Test for the All Blacks it plunged Australia rugby further in the gloom after a woeful Super Rugby season where Australian teams lost all their 26 games to New Zealand opposition.\n\nIt was played before the lowest Bledisloe Cup Test crowd at Sydney's Olympic stadium of 54,846.\n\nThe All Blacks demoralised the tackle-shy Wallabies with a six-try opening half to have the game wrapped up by half-time after a 40-6 landslide.\n\nWhile the Australians looked promising in attack they were clueless in defence with the world champions looking capable of scoring in every attacking phase.\n\nThe Wallabies left the field to stunned silence with their already tenuous Bledisloe Cup hopes in tatters with the All Blacks at home in the potentially deciding game in Dunedin next week.\n\nThe All Blacks scored their first try with quick passes from skipper Kieran Read and winger Rieko Ioane to give blindside flanker Liam Squire a clear run to the try-line.\n\nBernard Foley kicked the Wallabies to trail by a point with a 17th-minute penalty after the All Blacks scrum was penalised.\n\nBut the All Blacks again found a way through the Australian defence when left-winger Ioane got on the outside of floundering Israel Folau to score for a 12-6 lead midway through the half.\n\nIoane was over again minutes later when Michael Hooper's pass went astray and Ryan Crotty sent Ioane racing away between the posts.\n\nThe Wallabies defence was shredded again and Crotty scored an easy try near the posts after Beauden Barrett handled twice in the lead-up.\n\nThe New Zealanders claimed their fifth try just before half-time when Sonny Bill Williams crashed over and Barrett's conversion stretched the world champions' lead to 33-6.\n\nThe All Blacks made a mockery of the threadbare Australian defence with a sixth try off a training ground move and a double to centre Crotty after a scrum win deep inside the Wallabies' territory.\n\nBarrett's conversion gave the All Blacks an impregnable 40-6 lead at half-time.\n\nIt got no better with fullback Damian McKenzie scoring his first Test try three minutes after the resumption and Barrett's sixth conversion extended the lead to 47-6.\n\nWinger Ben Smith's try hoisted the All Blacks to their highest ever score against the Wallabies 54-6 and with still 30 minutes left in the one-sided Test.\n\nDebutant winger Curtis Rona finally scored Australia's first try after 52 minutes and further tries to replacement Tevita Kuridrani and a runaway from Kurtley Beale gave the home supporters something to cheer.\n\nIsrael Folau crossed for Australia's fourth try 11 minutes from the end.\n\nThe All Blacks continued their domination of the Wallabies and have lost only three of their last 30 encounters.\n\nAFP\n\nLike us on Facebook\n\nFollow us on Twitter", "originalArticle": Championship clash to New Zealand, with the All Blacks clocking up a record score against their great rivals.\n\nThe Wallabies were facing severe embarrassment in Sydney as they trailed 40-6 at half-time, and the All Blacks extended their lead to 54-6 after the break.\n\nThe visitors' summer exertions against the British and Irish Lions perhaps caught up with them in the second period and Australia cashed in, scoring 28 points, but New Zealand ran out comfortable 54-34 winners.\n\nIt will go down as a terrific result for Steve Hansen's men, who were home and hosed by the interval.\n\nLiam Squire had them in front 10 minutes in with the first of 12 tries on the day, but two Bernard Foley penalties kept Australia in the hunt at 7-6.\n\nRead more Kaino flies home from "person", "id": "1272251"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Joe Moody"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Moody", "type": "person", "id": "1272418"}], "body": "SYDNEY (AP) Damian McKenzie, Rieko Ioane and Liam Squire had starring roles as New Zealand ran in eight tries to four to beat Australia 54-34 Saturday in the first test of the Rugby Championship.\n\nWinger Ioane scored a double in the Bledisloe Cup opener to take his tally of tries to five from four test appearances. Fullback McKenzie got his first try in three tests, and flanker Squire scored his second try in eight tests as the All Blacks led 40-6 at halftime - and six tries to nil.\n\nAustralia rallied with four converted tries in the second half, to winger Curtis Rona on debut, centers Tevita Kuridrani and Kurtley Beale, and fullback Israel Folau.\n\nNew Zealand's points score in Australia exceeded its 51-20 win in 2014, though the winning margin fell short of its record 43-6 victory in 1996. At one point Saturday, the All Blacks led 54-6.\n\nThe result fomented a deeper crisis within Australian rugby which was already struggling after its worst-ever Super Rugby season in which its teams lost all 26 matches against New Zealand opponents.\n\nThe Wallabies hoped to bring some solace to fans who have begun to turn away from the sport because of administrative issues and poor on-field performance. Instead, they compounded the impression that the sport in Australia is in disarray.\n\nNew Zealand should have won more convincingly but lost its way after halftime.\n\n\"I think in the second half we let frustration strangle us a little bit,\" All Blacks captain Kieran Read said. \"We just needed to dump that and get back to playing some simple footy.\n\n\"We showed in the first half we really just let the ball do the work - nothing special but it just worked for us. I think the first half was good and we were okay in patches of the second half but we conceded 34 points which means most days of the week you're going to be losing test matches. But you can't fault that first half. It was bloody fantastic.\"\n\nMcKenzie played creative roles in an early try for Squire and in Ioane's double, after Australia had led with a third-minute penalty to Bernard Foley.\n\nThe fullback's line-break began the movement in the 18th minute, leading to Squire being given a wide corridor down the left-hand touch to outflank the Wallabies' defense. Beauden Barrett's conversion gave the All Blacks a 7-3 lead on which they built steadily throughout the first half.\n\nMcKenzie was again instrumental in making Ioane's first try, breaking the defense and leaving the winger to win an easy one-on-one with Folau, who rushed out of position.\n\nIoane had his double when a rushed pass caused Beale to cough up possession to Ryan Crotty, who drew defenders before allowing the pacy winger to sprint away.\n\nCrotty had his first try in the 25th minute after prop Joe Moody and lock Brodie Retallick had broken the Australian defense and McKenzie combined with Barrett to leave the line open.\n\nSonny Bill Williams crashed over in the 34th, then Crotty scored his second try when scrumhalf Aaron Smith passed to him directly from an attacking scrum in the last minute of the first half.\n\nThe All Blacks took a 40-6 lead to halftime and the game was already over. New Zealand had taken a major step toward retaining the Bledisloe Cup which it has held since 2003.\n\nIts grip on the match became more emphatic when McKenzie scored a brilliant try in the third minute of the second half, then Ben Smith added another from a break by Squire.\n\nNew Zealand seemed headed for an historic winning margin but the tide turned from then on.\n\nRona scored a good try from a set move at a scrum in the 52nd to lift Australian spirits. Kuridrani came off the bench and scored a neat try from a double-round in midfield to make the score 54-20.\n\nBeale, playing his first test since the 2015 World Cup final between Australia and New Zealand, pounced on a loose ball and dashed away in the 62nd, then Folau scored a contentious try, which appeared to begin from a forward pass by Foley and to continue with an offside play by Folau.\n\nThe All Blacks might have surpassed 60 points with a late try to Barrett but the score was overruled by the television official.\n\n\"The Wallabies were certainly going to come out firing in that second half. They did and we just took our foot off the throat a bit,\" Read said. \"We'll take the positives and there's obviously things to learn from. It's not often you come here and put 50 points on the Wallabies.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3374401", "id": "10059971", "url": "http://www.foxsports.com/rugby/story/rugby-championship-8-tries-for-nz-in-54-34-win-v-australia-081917", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "details": {}, "uri": "711904441", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "https://b.fssta.com/uploads/2017/08/201708190649245414032-p2.vresize.440.220.high.0.jpeg", "timeCrawl": "12:57:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T12:57:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Rugby Championship: 8 tries for NZ in 54-34 win v Australia | FOX Sports", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Sydney"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "Australia"}, "type": "country"}, "type": "place"}, "categories": [], "time": "12:57:00", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com", "title": "FOX Sports", "id": "276"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "SYDNEY, Australia -- And the Wallabies thought that was bad a night out 12 months ago.\n\nAustralian rugby sank to a horrifying new low at ANZ Stadium on Saturday night as a ruthless All Blacks outfit vented their frustrations from the drawn British & Irish Lions series, dishing out a rugby lesson to a Wallabies side that was little more than cannon fodder. Well, for 50 minutes anyway.\n\nThe Bledisloe opener looked more like a Rugby World Cup game featuring New Zealand and a minnow nation as the Wallabies had little answer to the All Blacks' mix of speed, power and skill. That the Australians missed a double-decker busload of tackles certainly did help their cause.\n\nEarly on it appeared the Wallabies might offer some sort of opposition as they moved up field, at times even threatening to poke their noses through the defensive line. But they could manage only two penalties while the All Blacks ripped through the heart of the Australian defence, dancing down the touchline with effortless ease.\n\nLiam Squire set the tone for a scintillating half of attacking rugby from the All Blacks when he skipped down the left touchline for the game's opening try on 10 minutes, before Rieko Ioane and Ryan Crotty added doubles, and Sonny Bill Williams wrote his name on the scoresheet before halftime. Job done.\n\nThe home fans among the 54,846 on hand looked on in stunned disbelief with the score at 40-6 at the break while their All Blacks counterparts beamed from ear to ear - the controversial finish to the Lions series now nothing more than a distant memory.\n\nPlaying just his third Test, Super Rugby's standout player of 2017 Damian McKenzie enjoyed a marvellous first Bledisloe foray; the diminutive but elusive fullback cutting through the Wallabies at ease as he helped set the platform for a handful of the All Blacks' six first-half tries. But it was the All Blacks' collective catch-and-pass skillset that shone, something that went missing for much of the final two Tests against the Lions.\n\nAnd then there was the tissue-paper-like Wallabies defence that fell off tackles, made terrible defensive decisions and basically lacked any desire whatsoever to hurt the All Blacks in the tackle.\n\nThe Wallabies compounded their missed tackles with simple errors in attack, an offer the All Blacks gleefully accepted just four minutes after the break when McKenzie was rewarded for his stellar first half via an unselfish Ioane. Four minutes later it was Ben Smith's turn, the only surprise that it had taken Ben Smith 48 minutes to get in on the action.\n\nWith 48 minutes on the clock, the All Blacks had scored 54 points.\n\nIt certainly won't be an evening that Wallabies debutant Curtis Rona forgets in a hurry, but at least he had a try on his Test bow to soften the blow. Rona's five-pointer stemmed the flow of 47 straight All Blacks points, and the Wallabies soon had their second through replacement Tevita Kuridrani, who worked a one-two with Folau to cut through the All Blacks' defence. Suddenly it was only 54-20.\n\nKurtley Beale further reduced the gap again when he swooped on a loose ball and ran 50 metres to score the Wallabies third just after the hour mark, adding further respectability to the contest.\n\nIn what was a bizarre final quarter, Folau was then awarded a try despite what looked to be giant forward pass from Bernard Foley. But neither referee Wayne Barnes, assistant Nigel Owens nor the Television Match Official saw it that way and the margin was now just a paltry 20 points.\n\nBut it did little more than paper over the Grand Canyon-like cracks in this Wallabies outfit. The job done, and then some, by halftime, it was no surprise the All Blacks eased up. The world champions proving a major point on the paddock, after a tumultuous week off it. Coach Steve Hansen won't be thrilled by the way his side faded to finish with the 54-34 win, but he will be ecstatic with what was a devastatingly brilliant first 50 minutes.\n\nAnd the All Blacks know they are now just 80 minutes away from another year of ownership of the Bledisloe Cup. That job, in all likelihood, will be completed in Dunedin in seven days' time.\n\nIt's up to the Wallabies to make a game of it. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Rugby_Union", "type": "wiki", "id": "407266"}], "body": "SYDNEY (AP) An increasingly acrimonious rivalry between the All Blacks and Wallabies has become more pronounced ahead of their first test of the Rugby Championship on Saturday.\n\nA sex scandal involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper on the eve of the Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, and a Sydney court is hearing a case concerning the discovery of a listening device in the All Blacks' hotel before a match in Sydney last season.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby has moved quickly to try to shut down the Smith scandal by appointing an independent lawyer to review its handling of the matter when it first arose last year.\n\nThe bugging controversy is more complicated and has done more than anything else to sour relations between the Australian and New Zealand teams.\n\nIn the week before last year's Bledisloe Cup test, the All Blacks claimed to have found a listening device embedded in a chair in their team room at a Sydney Hotel: the room in which tactics are often discussed.\n\nThe discovery was made by an Australian security contractor, Adrian Gard, who had worked with the All Blacks team for more than a decade.\n\nThe All Blacks informed hotel management early in the week, but opted against calling in police until the morning of the match - when the story was reported by a New Zealand newspaper.\n\nThe Australian Rugby Union was angry the All Blacks kept silent on the incident for so long and suspected they leaked it to media for a match day distraction.\n\nAustralia coach Michael Cheika was more incensed, thinking the All Blacks had implied the Wallabies were in some way responsible.\n\n\"They had that the whole week. That showed a lack of respect,\" Cheika said. \"I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organized. I am too busy working on my own thing.\"\n\nCheika has had a frosty relationship with his All Blacks counterpart Steve Hansen as he maintains his conviction that the bugging plot was hatched to discredit the Wallabies.\n\nGard has pleaded not guilty to a charge of public mischief, with police alleging he made a false claim regarding the bug.\n\nHansen is adamant the All Blacks have never implied the Wallabies were involved in the bugging incident.\n\n\"I don't know where they feel the inference was,\" Hansen said. \"We don't know who put it there. I said that at the time and that hasn't changed.\"\n\nThe Smith controversy has also intruded into the All Blacks' match preparation.\n\nA newspaper quoted a woman who had a sexual encounter with Smith at Dunedin Airport last September as saying Smith encouraged her to lie about the incident.\n\nSmith was suspended for a week after being sent home before a test match in South Africa but the newspaper alleges New Zealand Rugby didn't have the full facts when it levied punishment. New Zealand Rugby has opened a fresh inquiry to consider the new evidence.\n\nAt his news conference Thursday, Hansen raised the Smith issue before reporters asked.\n\n\"Obviously the incident happened last year. We dealt with it and we feel that we dealt with it decisively,\" Hansen said. \"There's nothing more that I can add to that but if there is anything else that needs to be spoken about, it will come from the New Zealand Rugby Union.\"\n\nThe issues swirling about the All Blacks might help decrease pressure on the Wallabies at a time of turmoil in Australian rugby. The poor performance of Australia's Super Rugby teams and the failure of the Australian Rugby Union in the process of cutting one of those teams next season has damaged the sport.\n\nA heavy loss by the Wallabies might compound those problems but Cheika has been able to prepare his players in relative quiet while the All Blacks have had to deal with off-field issues.\n\nCheika was able to name his team without undue scrutiny of his decision to include on one wing Curtis Rona - a rugby league convert who has played 80 minutes at winger in his short rugby union career. The All Blacks team announcement, which could have concentrated on a reorganized back three and the dropping of veteran flanker Jerome Kaino, instead was overshadowed by Smith and bugging.\n\n--\n\nAP Sports Writer Steve McMorran contributed from Wellington, New Zealand", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "9813743", "url": "http://www.foxsports.com/rugby/story/all-blacks-wallabies-take-rivalry-off-field-before-1st-test-081717", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "details": {}, "uri": "711222886", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "https://b.fssta.com/uploads/2017/08/201708161520552536088-p2-3.vresize.440.220.high.0.jpeg", "timeCrawl": "03:07:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:07:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "All Blacks, Wallabies take rivalry off field before 1st test | FOX Sports", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Sydney"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "Australia"}, "type": "country"}, "type": "place"}, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football", "id": 31}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_Union", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby Union", "id": 46}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "id": 47}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "id": 757}], "time": "03:07:00", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com", "title": "FOX Sports", "id": "276"}, "date": "2017-08-18", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18"}

whitewash.\n\nMartin Landajo and Emiliano Boffelli claimed tries for the ever attack-minded Pumas, but the visitors were unable to contain the Springboks' power, especially at the set-piece.\n\nSkosan and Rhule registered their first Test tries as the Springboks got their Rugby Championship campaign up and running in style.\n\nRaymond Rhule breaks through the Argentinian defence (Getty)\n\nElton Jantjies slotted three penalties to add to his four conversions, while Nicolas Sanchez posted a penalty for Argentina and Juan Martin Hernandez converted Boffelli's try.\n\nSouth Africa were made to Squire had starring roles as New Zealand ran in eight tries to four to beat Australia 54-34 yesterday in the first test of the Rugby Championship.\n\nWinger Ioane scored a double in the Bledisloe Cup opener to take his tally to five from four test appearances. Full-back McKenzie got his first try in three tests, and flanker Squire scored his second try in eight tests as the All Blacks led 40-6 at half-time - and six tries to nil.\n\nAustralia rallied with four converted second-half tries - from winger Curtis Rona on his debut, centres Tevita Kuridrani and Kurtley Beale, and full-back Israel Folau.\n\nNew Zealand's score exceeded its 51-20 win in 2014, though the winning margin fell short of its record 43-6 victory in 1996. At one point, the All Blacks led 54-6.\n\nThe Wallabies hoped to bring some solace to fans who have begun to turn away from the sport because of administrative issues and poor on-field performance. Instead, they compounded the impression that the sport in Australia is in disarray - and New Zealand should have won more convincingly.\n\n\"I think in the second half we let frustration strangle us a little bit,\" All Blacks captain Kieran Read said. \"We just needed to get back to playing some simple footy.\n\n\"We showed in the first half that we really just let the ball do the work. We were OK in patches of the second half but we conceded 34 points which means most days of the week you're going to be losing test matches. But you can't fault that first half. It was bloody fantastic.\"\n\nMcKenzie played creative roles in an early try for Squire, and in Ioane's double, after Australia had led with a third-minute penalty by Bernard Foley.\n\nThe full-back's line-break began the movement in the 18th minute, leading to Squire outflanking the Wallabies defence.
