"type": "person", "id": "1272418"}], "body": "Australia 34-54 New Zealand: All Blacks rack up record points tally against Wallabies By Michael Cantillon\n\nLast Updated: 19/08/17 1:55pm\n\nNew Zealand registered a record points tally over Australia in a Test match as they began their Rugby Championship defence with a crushing 54-34 victory in Sydney.\n\nThe All Blacks scored eight tries through Liam Squire, Rieko Ioane (2), Ryan Crotty (2), Sonny Bill Williams, Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith.\n\nAustralia scored four of their own in the second period through Curtis Rona, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau to add some respectability to the scoreline.\n\nAustralia now travel to face the All Blacks in Dunedin next Saturday.\n\nA frenetic start saw Australia break around the corner after lovely hands from second-row Sam Arnold and prop Scott Sio, and after several phases of pressure New Zealand were pinged for offside under their own posts and Bernard Foley stepped up to give the Wallabies a 3-0 lead after four minutes.\n\nNew Zealand responded within five minutes though through blindside flanker Squire, who showed great pace to burn past Samu Kerevi and race into the corner after McKenzie had make the original break and Kieran Read showed great hands to ship it on.\n\nAustralia responded with more forays into the 22 and after Owen Franks was pinged for pushing early and going to his knees at the next scrum, Foley kicked his second penalty of the game to bring them back to within one at 7-6 down.\n\nFrom the restart the All Blacks regained possession off a short kick-off, however, and after McKenzie and Ben Smith made good yards, New Zealand generated quick ball to Ioane, who checked Folau and finished well in the same corner that Squire had before him for their second try.\n\nIoane had his second and New Zealand's third try two minutes later after Crotty intercepted Foley's pass and shipped it onto the wing, who sprinted clear under the sticks.\n\nCrotty then scored a try of his own as Australia could not live with the All Blacks' intensity and pace.\n\nA flowing move started when prop Joe Moody sold a dummy and made good ground before offloading to lock Brodie Retallick, who produced a wonderful step, and from there quick ball saw Beauden Barrett find Crotty and the centre dived over from close range for a 26-6 lead after just 26 minutes.\n\nWilliams then crashed over for his 11th Test try on 34 minutes as he bulldozed past Speight and went over with the Australia defence increasingly porous after more quick ball from an All Black five-metre lineout.\n\nIn the final minute of the half Australia were penalised in their 22 again and after Read called a scrum, a set-piece move saw Crotty go over once more after Williams drew in two men.\n\nAmazingly, after Barrett's conversion, the All Blacks went in at the break with a lead of 40-6; a scoring rate of a point a minute.\n\nTwo minutes into the second period and the onslaught continued as Barrett ripped the ball off Hooper on half-way and found Ioane, who fed McKenzie on his shoulder with a clear run-in for his first Test try.\n\nBen Smith got in on the act after Squire cut through three attempted Wallby tackles and his namesake Aaron Smith found him on the inside, before Australia scored their first tries of the game through Rona on debut and replacement Kuridrani.\n\nBeale kept the spirited Wallabies response going when he raced away for an intercept try before Folau collected a ball which went to deck off Kuridrani's knee and ran in to "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Rugby_Union", "type": "wiki", "id": "407266"}], "body": "Sydney (AP) -- An increasingly acrimonious rivalry between the All Blacks and Wallabies has become more pronounced ahead of their first test of the Rugby Championship on Saturday.\n\nA sex scandal involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper on the eve of the Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, as well as a Sydney court hearing a case concerning the discovery of a listening device in the All Blacks' hotel before the corresponding test in Sydney last August.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby has moved quickly to try to shut down the Smith scandal by appointing an independent lawyer to review its handling of the matter when it first arose last year.\n\nThe bugging controversy, which ended Friday with the security consultant involved found not guilty, was more complicated and did more than anything else to sour relations between the Australian and New Zealand teams.\n\nIn the week before last year's Bledisloe Cup test, the All Blacks claimed to have found a listening device embedded in a chair in their team room at a Sydney Hotel: the room in which tactics are often discussed.\n\nThe discovery was made by an Australian security contractor, Adrian Gard, who had worked with the All Blacks team for more than a decade.\n\nThe All Blacks informed hotel management early in the week, but opted against calling in police until the morning of the match -- when the story was reported by a New Zealand newspaper.\n\nIn the Downing Centre Local Court on Friday, Magistrate Jennifer Atkinson found Gard not guilty of making a false representation resulting in a police investigation, saying there was not enough evidence.\n\nAtkinson did, however, find Gard guilty of a second charge of acting as a security consultant without the proper license.\n\nThe incident last year caused friction between the neighboring teams, with the Australian Rugby Union angry the All Blacks kept silent on the incident for so long and suspected they leaked it to media for a match day distraction.\n\nAustralia coach Michael Cheika was more incensed, thinking the All Blacks had implied the Wallabies were in some way responsible.\n\n\"They had that the whole week. That showed a lack of respect,\" Cheika said. \"I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organized. I am too busy working on my own thing.\"\n\nCheika has had a frosty relationship with his All Blacks counterpart Steve Hansen as he maintains his conviction that the bugging plot was hatched to discredit the Wallabies.\n\nHansen is adamant the All Blacks have never implied the Wallabies were involved in the bugging incident.\n\n\"I don't know where they feel the inference was,\" Hansen said. \"We don't know who put it there. I said that at the time and that hasn't changed.\"\n\nThe Smith controversy has also intruded into the All Blacks' match preparation.\n\nA newspaper quoted a woman who had a sexual encounter with Smith at Dunedin Airport last September as saying Smith encouraged her to lie about the incident.\n\nSmith was suspended for a week after being sent home before a test match in South Africa but the newspaper alleges New Zealand Rugby didn't have the full facts when it levied punishment. New Zealand Rugby has opened a fresh inquiry to consider the new evidence.\n\nAt his news conference Thursday, Hansen raised the Smith issue before reporters asked.\n\n\"Obviously the incident happened last year. We dealt with it and we feel that we dealt with it decisively,\" Hansen said. \"There's nothing more that I can add to that but if there is anything else that needs to be spoken about, it will come from the New Zealand Rugby Union.\"\n\nThe issues swirling about the All Blacks might help decrease pressure on the Wallabies at a time of turmoil in Australian rugby. The poor performance of Australia's Super Rugby teams and the failure of the Australian Rugby Union in the process of cutting one of those teams next season has damaged the sport.\n\nA heavy loss by the Wallabies might compound those problems but Cheika has been able to prepare his players in relative quiet while the All Blacks have had to deal with off-field issues.\n\nCheika was able to name his team without undue scrutiny of his decision to include on one wing Curtis Rona -- a rugby league convert who has played 80 minutes at winger in his short rugby union career. on deck and young gun Sean McMahon adding aggression to the back row - command respect.\n\nHansen also believes Australian sides' poor Super Rugby season, with only the Brumbies making the quarter-finals, may benefit the Wallabies.\n\n\"They've got a lot of talent and they've had a great preparation,\" he said on Thursday.\n\n\"While franchise fans weren't probably overexcited about the fact that they got knocked out early and would rather have seen them play right through to the final and have less preparation time, those two things make them a dangerous beast.\n\n\"The third thing that makes the really dangerous is their desire to try to help Australian rugby and at the moment it has a bit of a cloud over it and they haven't won the Bledisloe in a long time.\n\n\"They're pretty hungry for it so, as a team, we have to be hungrier than them, otherwise we're at a disadvantage.\"\n\nHansen also fears being the first All Blacks coach to hand back the prized piece of trans-Tasman silverware since 1998.\n\n\"Bledisloe is something we hold dearly in New Zealand rugby and someone's going to lose it and you don't want to be that person,\" he said.\n\n\"But you don't want to be burdened by that either. That's an important thing.\n\n\"It's the biggest trophy we play for outside of the World Cup and it means a lot to the group - it's part of who are we, and our legacy is about honouring, respecting and enhancing the jersey,.\n\n\"We've held this trophy for a while, and no one wants to be part of giving it up.\"\n\nThe All Blacks racked up an aggregate of 107 points, while conceding just 29, in last year's three-Test whitewash yet Hansen maintains the world champions retain a healthy respect for the Wallabies.\n\n\"Australia and New Zealand have done a lot of things together and not just play rugby and all sports,\" he said.\n\n\"And it's a big brother-little brother backyard game and the little brother doesn't like losing to the big brother and the big brother certainly doesn't like losing to the little brother. It creates a tension.\n\n\"And when the little brother appears to be winning more than he should be, you probably get a little bit hacked off about it and it does create a bit of resentment.\n\n\"But I think the rivalry is good. Aug 19 (Reuters) - Ghana-born wing Raymond Rhule scored his first international try as South Africa claimed a 37-15 bonus-point victory over Argentina in their Rugby Championship opener on Saturday.\n\nThe Springboks dominated the physical contest and scored tries through winger Courtnall Skosan, flanker Siya Kolisi and lock Pieter-Steph du Toit, their fourth victory in a row after a 3-0 clean-sweep of France.\n\nArgentina defended manfully and enjoyed little possession, but managed tries through experienced scrumhalf Martin Landajo and winger Emiliano Boffelli.\n\nThe Springboks also handed a first cap to 20-year-old flyhalf Curwin Bosch when he replaced Elton Jantjies late in the game.\n\n\"We couldn\u00b4t have asked for a better start (to the competition),\" Bok captain Eben Etzebeth said at the post-match presentation.\n\n\"We said at halftime we must keep going and the ball will break for us. We got some more tries in the second half and the bonus point, which is important for us.\"\n\nAfter a miserable 2016 in which they lost eight of their 12 tests, signs of a Bok revival continued as they won key battles against the Argentines.\n\nThe home side were dominant in the scrum and held their defensive shape well, offering little space for the visitors to exploit.\n\nThe Boks dominated possession in the opening half, but after Jantjies had kicked two penalties, it was the visitors who scored the opening try against the run of play when they completed a swift break in the corner after Jan Serfontein\u00b4s attempted grubber kick was scooped up and Landajo sent clear to dot down.\n\nBut a moment of magic by Skosan just before halftime, coupled with some weak Argentine defence, allowed the wing to score his maiden international try as the Boks headed into the break with a 13-5 advantage.\n\nThe teams traded penalties early in the second period, before the Boks took control of the game when Rhule rounded off some slick handling to cross for his try.\n\nAt that stage the Boks led by 15 points, but that was cut to seven when Boffelli crossed in the corner for the visitors after some concerted pressure in the home 22.\n\nWith 20 minutes to go the game was still in the balance, though the Boks continued to dominate possession and territory, and they made sure of the win as Kolisi and Du Toit crossed for tries against the wilting Argentine defence.\n\n\"South Africa had a great game,\" said Landajo. \"We need to improve at the breakdown, the ball was very slow. yesterday.\n\nThe Wallabies have a chance to lift some of the gloom hanging over Australian rugby tomorrow, but to do so they will have to achieve the considerable feat of upsetting the All Blacks in the Rugby Championship opener.\n\nA miserable Super Rugby campaign, during which none of the nation's five teams beat New Zealand-based opponents in 26 attempts, was accompanied by the bitter and protracted effort to shut down the Western Force.\n\nWhile that public-relations disaster rumbled on, Australia coach Michael Cheika has had his players in a training camp for a month, plotting to take down the world champions in the first of three Bledisloe Cup Tests this year.\n\nThat lengthy preparation time and the talent at Cheika's disposal makes the Wallabies a \"dangerous beast,\" All Blacks coach Steve Hansen said yesterday.\n\n\"The third thing that makes them really dangerous is their desire to try to help Australian rugby and at the moment it has a bit of a cloud over it,\" Hansen told reporters. \"They haven't won the Bledisloe in a long time and they're pretty hungry for it so, as a team, we have to be hungrier than them, otherwise we're at a disadvantage.\"\n\nAustralia have not held the trophy that symbolizes tran-Tasman rugby supremacy since 2002 and the bookmakers do not share Hansen's caution, making the All Blacks 1-10 favorites to win at the Olympic Stadium.\n\nMoreover, New Zealand begin the defense of their Rugby Championship title feeling they have a point to prove after losing a Test at home for the first time in eight years during the drawn British and Irish Lions series in June.\n\nHansen has summoned the latest explosive back off the New Zealand production line by awarding Damian McKenzie the start at fullback and slotted the rugged Liam Squire into his back row to give Jerome Kaino a rest.\n\nSonny Bill Williams is back in the centers after serving his four-match ban for the red card he was shown during the Lions series and he is to line up opposite Kurtley Beale, who plays his first Test since the 2015 World Cup final.\n\nThat run leading up to the world title decider at Twickenham is now a distant memory for Australian rugby fans, who have had to get used to regular losses in the intervening two years.\n\nIt was a Sydney victory over the All Blacks in the truncated Rugby Championship of 2015 that really sparked the run to the World cup final and Cheika knows exactly the kind of effort that will be required to replicate it tomorrow.\n\n\"I just want to see them enjoying the battle,\" Cheika said yesterday. \"It's gonna be a big battle. rugby with a record-setting 54-34 Bledisloe Cup win in Sydney.\n\nMichael Cheika is vowing to stick by defensive coach Nathan Grey despite the Wallabies leaking eight tries against the All Blacks for the first time in 81 years.\n\nCheika condemned the Wallabies' diabolical tackling after the All Blacks opened the Rugby Championship with a record-setting 54-34 rout in Sydney on Saturday.\n\nThe rampant world champions piled on six tries in the first half alone in racking up their highest total against Australia in 114 years of trans-Tasman Test battles.\n\n\"It was pretty plain to see that our defence wasn't good enough, at all,\" Cheika said.\n\n\"The adherence to the way we want to defend plus also the tackling in itself, it's got to be better.\n\n\"That first part of the game was not the level that you can be at - not in any game, let alone against them.\"\n\nThe Wallabies missed 39 tackles in a disastrous first-half performance that left any realistic hopes of winning back the Bledisloe Cup in 2017 in tatters.\n\nYet Cheika will continue backing Grey's defensive system, saying the Wallabies' problems stemmed from indecision.\n\n\"It's not attitude. It's maybe that little bit of doubt creeps in,\" he said.\n\n\"When something goes against you early - and we've been preparing a certain way - if it creeps in, a little bit of doubt, (you're thinking) half, will go I? will I hedge? That causes some of the problems.\"\n\nAsked if he'd persist with Grey and his structures, Cheika said: \"One hundred per cent ... one hundred per cent\".\n\nThe contest was over at halftime, with the All Blacks leading 40-6 after try-scoring doubles to Rieko Ioane and Ryan Crotty, further five-pointers to Liam Squire and Sonny Bill Williams and five conversions to Beauden Barrett.\n\nThe onslaught continued immediately upon the resumption as the All Blacks surged to a 54-6 lead in 48 minutes after chalking up eight tries against Australia for the first time since 1936.\n\nA crowd of just 54,846 fans - the lowest-ever for a Bledisloe battle at ANZ Stadium - witnessed one of the Wallabies' lowest-ever performances.\n\nConsolation replies to Curtis Rona on debut, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau flattered the Wallabies, who were outclassed in every facet of play.\n\n\"It's not the start we'd hoped for in this series and in particular this game,\" said Wallabies captain Michael Hooper.\n\nIf history is any guide, the Bledisloe Cup will remain in New Zealand hands for a 15th straight year with the Wallabies having never won a series after losing the first match at home.\n\nThe two sides square off again next Saturday in Dunedin with Cheika's demoralised troops needing to somehow conjure a first win across the Tasman since 2001 to keep the series alive before involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith\n\nAustralia host Rugby Championship holders New Zealand, with the world champions hoping to return to winning ways following their engrossing Test series with the British and Irish Lions.\n\nThe Kiwis have travelled to Sydney for the opening game of this year's competition on Saturday, and coach Steve Hansen has made six changes to the side that drew the third Test against the Lions in July.\n\nSonny Bill Williams will start at centre for the All Blacks after completing a four-match ban and he joined his team-mates for the captain's run on the eve of the contest.\n\nSteve Hansen and Michael Cheika will go head to head on Saturday in the Bledisloe Cup clash\n\nSonny Bill Williams takes a selfie with some of the supporters who attended the session\n\nNew Zealand's Kieran Read speaks to the media during their captain's run training session\n\nAn increasingly acrimonious rivalry between the All Blacks and Wallabies has become more pronounced ahead of their first test of the Rugby Championship on Saturday.\n\nA sex scandal involving All Blacks scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper on the eve of the Bledisloe Cup match at the Olympic stadium, and a Sydney court is hearing a case concerning the discovery of a listening device in the All Blacks' hotel before a match in Sydney last season.\n\nNew Zealand Rugby has moved quickly to try to shut down the Smith scandal by appointing an independent lawyer to review its handling of the matter when it first arose last year.\n\nThe bugging controversy is more complicated and has done more than anything else to sour relations between the Australian and New Zealand teams.\n\nA sex scandal involving scrumhalf Aaron Smith has been revived by an Australian newspaper\n\nJoe Moody is put through his paces during training ahead of the Rugby Championship opener\n\nIn the week before last year's Bledisloe Cup test, the All Blacks claimed to have found a listening device embedded in a chair in their team room at a Sydney Hotel: the room in which tactics are often discussed.\n\nThe discovery was made by an Australian security contractor, Adrian Gard, who had worked with the All Blacks team for more than a decade.\n\nThe All Blacks informed hotel management early in the week, but opted against calling in police until the morning of the match - when the story was reported by a New Zealand newspaper.\n\nThe Australian Rugby Union was angry the All Blacks kept silent on the incident for so long and suspected they leaked it to media for a match day distraction.\n\nAustralia coach Michael Cheika was more incensed, thinking the All Blacks had implied the Wallabies were in some way responsible.\n\nDamian McKenzie handles the all in the low sunshine at the Sydney Oval on Friday morning\n\nAustralia will have to be watchful of Beauden Barrett should they conceded penalties\n\n'They had that the whole week. That showed a lack of respect,' Cheika said.\n\n'I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organized. I am too busy working on my own thing.'\n\nCheika has had a frosty relationship with his All Blacks counterpart Steve Hansen as he maintains his conviction that the bugging plot was hatched to discredit the Wallabies.\n\nGard has pleaded not guilty to a charge of public mischief, with police alleging he made a false claim regarding the bug.\n\nHansen is adamant the All Blacks have never implied the Wallabies were involved in the bugging incident.\n\n'I don't know where they feel the inference was,' Hansen said. 'We don't know who put it there. I said that at the time and that hasn't changed.'\n\nThe Smith controversy has also intruded into the All Blacks' match preparation.\n\nSonny Bill Williams walks during their captain's run training session at the North Sydney Oval\n\nBeauden Barrett holds the ball during one drill with the backs as the Kiwis gear up for the game\n\nAUSTRALIA VS NEW ZELAND (KICK-OFF: 11AM BST)\n\nAUSTRALIA\n\nStarting XV: Israel Folau, Henry Speight, Samu Kerevi, Kurtley Beale, Curtis Rona, Bernard Foley, Will Genia; Scott Sio, Stephen Moore, Allan Alaalatoa, Rory Arnold, Adam Coleman, Ned Hanigan, Michael Hooper, Sean McMahon\n\nReplacements: Tatafu Polota-Nau, Tom Robertson, Sekope Kepu, Rob Simmons, Lopeti Timani, Nick Phipps, Reece Hodge, Tevita Kuridrani\n\nNEW ZEALAND\n\nStarting XV: Damian McKenzie, Ben Smith, Ryan Crotty, Sonny Bill Williams, Rieko Ioane, Beauden Barrett, Aaron Smith; Joe Moody, Codie Taylor, Owen Franks, Brodie Retallick, Sam Whitelock, Liam Squire, Sam Cane, Kieran Read\n\nReplacements: Nathan Harris, Wyatt Crockett, Ofa Tu'ungafasi, Luke Romano, Ardie Savea, TJ Perenara, Lima Sopoaga, Anton Lienert-Brown\n\nA newspaper quoted a woman who had a sexual encounter with Smith at Dunedin Airport last September as saying Smith encouraged her to lie about the incident.\n\nSmith was suspended for a week after being sent home before a test match in South Africa but the newspaper alleges New Zealand Rugby didn't have the full facts when it levied punishment. New Zealand Rugby has opened a fresh inquiry to consider the new evidence.\n\nAt his news conference Thursday, Hansen raised the Smith issue before reporters asked.\n\n'Obviously the incident happened last year. We dealt with it and we feel that we dealt with it decisively,' Hansen said. 'There's nothing more that I can add to that but if there is anything else that needs to be spoken about, it will come from the New Zealand Rugby Union.'\n\nHansen knows neutral supporters will be hoping the Wallabies can put in a good performance\n\nThe Wallabies have home advantage with the game taking place in Sydney's ANZ Stadium\n\nTalisman Barrett is all smiles in the sunshine\n\nThe issues swirling about the All Blacks might help decrease pressure on the Wallabies at a time of turmoil in Australian rugby. The poor performance of Australia's Super Rugby teams and the failure of the Australian Rugby Union in the process of cutting one of those teams next season has damaged the sport.\n\nA heavy loss by the Wallabies might compound those problems but Cheika has been able to prepare his players in relative quiet while the All Blacks have had to deal with off-field issues.\n\nCheika was able to name his team without undue scrutiny of his decision to include on one wing Curtis Rona - a rugby league convert who has played 80 minutes at winger in his short rugby union career. "Bernard Foley"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "The Wallabies' hopes of regaining the Bledisloe Cup were all but dashed after a shocking first half against the All Blacks before they managed to salvage some pride in a bizarre 54-34 defeat in Sydney.\n\nA total of 12 tries were scored in an 88-point fixture that exposed some serious deficiencies in the Wallabies defence.\n\nIt was the second-most points the Wallabies have ever conceded and the third time in five years the All Blacks have piled on 40 points in a Bledisloe Cup opener in Sydney.\n\n\"Defence has been an issue,\" quipped Wallabies coach Michael Cheika at half-time in what was one of the understatements of the year.\n\nRelated Articles All Blacks star Kaino returns home for 'personal' reasons Hooper daring to dream of Bledisloe upset\n\nWhen Australia trailed 40-6 at the main break, there was little new skipper Michael Hooper could have said to his distraught troops in what has to be one of the most brutal introductions to full-time Wallabies captaincy.\n\nAt one stage the Wallabies were staring down the barrel of their worst defeat but four tries in 17 minutes - from Curtis Rona, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau - saved them plenty of embarrassment.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFor context, the Wallabies missed a staggering 40 per cent (37 from 94) of all tackles in the first half and there will be immense pressure on defence coach Nathan Grey given what the Waratahs dished up this year too.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Rugbyheaven Newsletter Rugbyheaven Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nBy the end of 80 minutes, Australia had missed 48 tackles, which is just not good enough at international level.\n\nIn last year's bloodbath against New Zealand in Sydney, the full-time margin was 34 points. On Saturday, the All Blacks led by that buffer at half-time.\n\nNew Zealand piled on an incredible six tries in the first half, which was more than they scored in the entire series against the British and Irish Lions.\n\nAnd when the All Blacks chalked up their eighth try in the 48th minute, thanks to a sensational pass back inside to Ben Smith from Aaron Smith, it marked the most points they had ever scored against Australia, from 182 matches.\n\nCheika may have boasted the Wallabies were fit and raring to go but they sure as anything didn't do enough work on their defensive structures in an abysmal effort.\n\nMeanwhile, after one of the most tumultuous weeks for New Zealand rugby in recent memory, the All Blacks were able to push to one side the off-field scandals and execute a game plan that completely blew the Wallabies off the park.\n\nHalfback Aaron Smith, whose \"toilet tryst\" last year resurfaced during the week as did fresh allegations of affairs with other women, had a brilliant game and was clearly unperturbed by what had transpired in recent days.\n\nCoach Steve Hansen's mind, however, would have been in two places hours before kick-off after it emerged New Zealand's team manager Darren Shand told police he believed Cheika was responsible for bugging the team's hotel last year.\n\nThe All Blacks, however, were more than able to separate on-field from off-field but will be annoyed they did not completely put Australia to the sword in the second half.\n\nTo the surprise of many, it was the Wallabies who got on the scoresheet first thanks to a penalty after four minutes to Bernard Foley on the back of some excellent attacking bursts in the All Blacks' 22.\n\nBut like they do so often, the All Blacks capitalised on a mistake from their opposition.\n\nAllan Alaalatoa knocked the ball on and shortly afterwards New Zealand were able to get auspicious front-foot ball before Liam Squire, Jerome Kaino's replacement, scored down the left edge.\n\nA Wallabies penalty brought the margin back to one point but that's about as good as it got for Cheika's men before a poor defensive read from Folau on the right edge saw Rieko Ioane put the visitors ahead 12-6.\n\nThe All Blacks, through Ioane and Ryan Crotty, then scored two tries in four minutes to put their tally at 26 points in as many minutes to silence a crowd of 54,846 at ANZ Stadium.\n\nAustralia's defensive line looked scrambled and they were unable to adapt on the run to countless questions asked by New Zealand's backs.\n\nRona scored a try on debut in the 52nd minute and when Kuridrani squeezed through a gap to go over the line in the 56th minute, Australia looked a completely different outfit.\n\nAttack-wise, there were things to like. Beale brought the flair we expected and scored Australia's third consecutive try when he scooped up a loose ball and ran 50 metres.\n\nThe 34 points the Wallabies racked up was actually the second-most against the All Blacks.\n\nThe bad news? Courtnall Skosan and Raymond Rhule scored their first Test tries as South Africa stretched a winning run to four Tests by defeating Argentina 37-15 Saturday in the Rugby Championship.\n\nSpringboks fly-half Elton Jantjies kicked 17 points at Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium in Port Elizabeth as the home team finished comfortable victors after leading 13-5 at half-time.\n\nThe triumph followed a 3-0 whitewash of France two months ago and continued a turnaround after a calendar-year record eight defeats in 12 Tests last season.\n\nArgentina were virtually always on the back foot, committing countless handling errors, conceding numerous penalties and fly-half Nicolas Sanchez had an off-day with his goal-kicking.\n\n\"We could not have asked for a better start to the Rugby Championship,\" said South Africa skipper and lock Eben Etzebeth.\n\n\"Our sincere thanks to the unbelievable support that we got here tonight,\" he added, referring to the almost-capacity crowd in the 46,000-seat stadium.\n\n\"I cannot wait for the return match next weekend -- we will start preparing tomorrow. We are really looking forward to next weekend.\n\n\"It is incredible how the boys play for each other. The culture in this team is amazing and it is great to be part of it.\"\n\nArgentina skipper and hooker Agustin Creevy said: \"I think South Africa played a great game, but were are fortunate to have another chance to beat them next weekend.\n\n\"Our ball from set pieces and the breakdown was very slow so we have to fix that problem quickly.\n\n\"We have great memories from last year of Salta, where we beat the Springboks, and I hope we can repeat that feat at the same ground next weekend.\n\n\"My team will try to use home advantage in our favour and we will try to gain from the support of our people.\"\n\nRelentless early pressure from South Africa finally paid off after 12 minutes when Jantjies slotted a penalty after flanker Tomas Lezana went off his feet at a ruck.\n\nJantjies doubled the lead on 20 minutes from another penalty with Lezana again the offender, this time caught offside by French referee Romain Poite.\n\nA six-point lead after 20 minutes was hardly the reward the Springboks deserved as they had kept the Pumas hemmed deep in their half on a cool, clear eastern Cape evening.\n\nIt took Argentina 27 minutes to reach the South African '22' and almost immediately Sanchez had a chance to score, but missed a kickable penalty attempt.\n\nHowever, five minutes later the South Americans did score when a grubber kick from centre Jan Serfontein was snapped up by full-back Joaquin Tuculet, who counterattacked.\n\nWinger Emiliano Boffelli carried forward the move and his clever kick ahead was snapped up by scrum-half Martin Landajo and he dotted down in the corner.\n\nSanchez failed to convert, leaving South Africa with a 6-5 ahead that did not reflect their possession and territory dominance.\n\nSouth Africa finally scored a try after 37 minutes as Skosan collected an inside pass from Jantjies, shrugged off a tackle and went over between the posts.\n\nJantjies converted and South Africa left the field at half-time full value for a 13-5 advantage.\n\nSanchez and Jantjies exchanged second-half penalties before Rhule burst between two Pumas to score his first try, which was converted.\n\nSlick handling sent Boffelli over at the other end and substitute fly-half Juan Martin Hernandez converted to leave the South Americans trailing 23-15 with an hour gone.\n\nSouth Africa controlled the final quarter and forwards Siya Kolisi Anton Lienert-Brown\n\nSideline officials: Nigel Owens (WAL) and Andy Brace (IRE)\n\nReview officials: Rowan Kitt (ENG)\n\nThe All Blacks have won their last five games against the Wallabies, the last time they won more was a 10-game streak from 2008 to 2010.\n\nNew Zealand posted a 42-8 win against Australia when they last met at ANZ Stadium, the biggest win in the history of the fixture at that venue (16 games).\n\nThe Wallabies have scored no more than a penalty goal in the opening half of each of their last three games at ANZ Stadium, trailing at halftime in each match, though they've gone on to earn a win and a draw in that period (L1).\n\nThe All Blacks have lost only one of their last seven games within Australia (W4, D2), and will be looking to win consecutive fixtures on Australian soil for the first time since winning four on the trot from 2008 to 2010.\n\nBen Smith has scored 16 tries from 23 fixture at The Rugby Championship, the equal third most of any player in the history of the competition while only one All Black (Richie McCaw, 17) has scored more.\n\nBeauden Barrett high-scored with a haul of 81 points in the 2016 iteration of The Rugby Championship, 28 more than next-best Bernard Foley and Nicolas Sanchez.\n\nLast time played: All Blacks 37 def Australia 10, October 22 2016\n\nLast time in Sydney: All Blacks 42 def Australia 8, August 20, 20116\n\nHead-to-head: Australia - $7.20 All Blacks - $1.09\n\nPre-match banter - Kieran Read is confident All Blacks will be ready for a hungry Wallabies outfit\n\nAll Blacks captain Kieran Read has stressed the importance of the Bledisloe Cup ahead of Saturday night's clash against Australia in Sydney.\n\nThe All Blacks have held the Cup since 2003 and the Wallabies are desperate to win it back.\n\nRead is expecting a determined Wallabies side to front at ANZ Stadium, but knows his side be motived to win the first of three Bledisloe Cup Test matches.\n\n\"For us it is an important cup,\" said Read.\n\n\"As All Blacks we don't take it for granted. None of us have been a part of a team that have lost it.\n\n\"We all know the history of the cup. It is very special to us as All Blacks and we know how hungry the Wallabies will be.\n\n\"It doesn't take much to motivate the guys, outside the World Cup it is our most special cup which we cherish and we want to do well in it.\"\n\nThe All Blacks are coming of an unexpected drawn series against the British and Irish Lions which left everybody speechless and our willingness I guess to where our strengths are which is to have an attacking mind set.\n\nRead knows some of the players might be lacking confidence after the series, and he knows the team has to be better if they are to win.\n\n\"We have to have our minds on the job.\n\n\"If they are not there tomorrow we will certainly get found out. Things have been spoken about but we have come here with one job in mind and that is out on the footy field.\n\n\"We need to be better than what we were a month ago. That is in our performance and in a bit of attitude from the boys.\n\n\"We can't wait to get out there as it is a highly anticipated clash. -\n\nBut they roared back in their inimitable fashion, posting an eight tries to four victory.\n\nWhile the All Blacks stamped their mark early on the Test match it was another blow to Australian rugby following a woeful Super Rugby season, where Australian teams lost all their 26 games to New Zealand opposition.\n\nAnother low was that the game was played before the smallest Bledisloe Cup Test crowd at Sydney's Olympic stadium of 54,846.\n\n\"It was pretty plain to see that our defence wasn't good enough at all,\" Wallabies coach Michael Cheika told reporters.\n\n\"The adherence to the way we wanted to defend plus the tackling in itself has got to be better. That first part of the game is not at the level that you can be at all.\"\n\nThe All Blacks demoralised the tackle-shy Wallabies with a six-try opening half blitz to have the game wrapped up by half-time after a 40-6 landslide.\n\nIoane was over again minutes later when Michael Hooper's pass went astray and Ryan Crotty sent Ioane racing away.\n\nThe Wallabies defence was shredded again and Crotty scored an easy try near the posts after Beauden Barrett handled twice in the lead-up.\n\nThe New Zealanders claimed their fifth try just before half-time when Sonny Bill Williams crashed over.\n\nThey made a mockery of the threadbare Australian defence with a sixth try off a rehearsed training ground move for centre Crotty's try double off a scrum win deep inside Wallabies' territory.\n\nBarrett's conversion gave the All Blacks an unassailable lead at half-time.\n\nIt got no better with fullback Damian McKenzie scoring his first Test try three minutes after the resumption, and winger Ben Smith's try hoisted the All Blacks to their highest ever score against the Wallabies with still 30 minutes left in an embarrassingly one-sided Test.\n\nDebutant winger Curtis Rona finally crossed for Australia's first try after 52 minutes and further tries to replacement Tevita Kuridrani and a runaway effort from Kurtley Beale gave the home supporters something to cheer about.\n\nFolau went over for Australia's fourth try 11 minutes from the end.\n\nThe All Blacks continue their domination of the Wallabies, losing only three of their last 30 encounters.", {"eng": "Joe Moody"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Moody", "type": "person", "id": "1272418"}], "body": "Will it be another Bledisloe Cup victory to the all-conquering All Blacks - or are the Wallabies about to experience a sudden form reversal, and knock off the best nation in the world?\n\nLet's be honest - it's probably going to be the former. Almost certainly. If it's the latter, we will all have our jaws hanging open at 10 o'clock tonight.\n\nThe simple facts are that New Zealand haven't lost their grip on the Bledisloe Cup for thirteen years now, and Australia have won just six Bledisloe Tests against the Kiwis in that time.\n\nNew Zealand have won the last five meetings in a row between the two nations, including four Bledisloe Tests and the 2015 Rugby World Cup final.\n\nThat doesn't mean Australia can't pinch the odd Test against the All Blacks here and there - and here, at ANZ Stadium, is the most likely place for it to happen.\n\nOf the six Bledisloe Tests the Wallabies have won since they last held the cup, three of them have come at this ground, including the most recent one.\n\nBut still to pull that off, the Wallabies will have to see a significant reversal of their recent form, both at club level and as a national team.\n\nIn their three June Tests, the Wallabies recorded passable but uninspiring wins over Fiji and Italy, and a disappointing loss to Scotland.\n\nMore concerningly, in the 2017 Super Rugby season, Australian sides played against New Zealand sides twenty six times, and the final record was... 0-26 in favour of New Zealand.\n\nWhat about the All Blacks? Well, after a tied series with the British and Irish Lions, they look probably as vulnerable as they have in recent years - which isn't very much.\n\nThey defeated the Lions 30-15 in the first Test, but then lost the second 21-24 and drew the final match 15-all.\n\nIt wasn't technically two losses in a row, but it was the first time the All Blacks have had two consecutive non-win results since... scrolling, scrolling... they lost to the Springboks and Wallabies back-to-back in 2011.\n\nThey haven't played three Tests without winning at least one of them since 1998. The odds don't bode well for the Wallabies.\n\nIf there had been something dramatic that happened to reverse the respective fortunes of either team in recent weeks, perhaps we could make an argument for the Wallabies' chances of an upset.\n\nBut all that could qualify is the ARU's decision to axe the Western Force, which you'd think is more likely to be a distraction than a boost.\n\nIn the end, perhaps all Australian rugby fans can hope for is another unexpected twist in the tale, one which will see the come from nowhere to claim victory.\n\n(AP Photo/Rob Griffith)\n\nKey information\n\nKick-off: 8pm (AEST), Saturday August 19\n\nVenue: ANZ Stadium, Sydney\n\nTV: Live, Fox Sports 501, Network Ten\n\nOnline: Live, Foxtel Now, Foxtel App, Tenplay\n\nBetting: All Blacks $1.05, Wallabies $9\n\nHead-to-head: All Blacks 127, Wallabies 48, seven draws\n\nLast five: All Blacks 5-0 Wallabies\n\nSquads\n\nWallabies\n\n1. Anton Lienert-Brown\n\nPrediction\n\nWe'd all love to be optimistic about the Wallabies, probably even New Zealand fans, who must almost be approaching getting sick of winning by this point. "Joe Moody"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Moody", "type": "person", "id": "1272418"}], "body": "Before kickoff in Sydney, there was a sense New Zealand could be run close by Australia in the Rugby Championship opener.\n\nThe All Blacks had conceded a drawn series to the British and Irish Lions, the backline was changed again, and off-field issues involving bugging, Aaron Smith, and Jerome Kaino were potentially distracting.\n\nBut then Australia kicked off on Saturday, and the All Blacks swept all of those concerns aside as easily as they did the Wallabies with a record 54-34 win.\n\nBy halftime they led 40-6, then 54-6 into the new half. That was already their highest score against the Wallabies, eclipsing 51 in 2014 in Auckland. But with utter humiliation achieved, the All Blacks let up, and Australia rallied with four tries to save a little face.\n\n\"You can't fault that first half. It was bloody fantastic,\" All Blacks captain Kieran Read said.\n\nNew Zealand scored eight tries, their most in 81 years against the Wallabies, who entered the match with a measure of confidence after a four-week camp. They'd also studied last year's opening loss to New Zealand, when they conceded 42 points and missed 38 tackles, and thought they sorted out that issue.\n\nBut the defense was nowhere to be seen as New Zealand sliced through Australia with ease in the first half.\n\n\"Our defense wasn't good enough at all,\" Australia coach Michael Cheika said. \"It's not attitude, it's maybe just that little bit of doubt creeps in. When something goes against you early and you have been preparing a certain way, in creeps a little bit of doubt.\"\n\nThe result fomented a deeper crisis within Australian rugby which was already struggling after its worst-ever Super Rugby season in which its teams lost all 26 matches against New Zealand opponents.\n\nThe Wallabies hoped to bring some solace to fans who have begun to turn away from the sport because of administrative issues and poor on-field performance. Instead, they compounded the impression that the sport in Australia is in disarray.\n\nNew Zealand fullback Damian McKenzie, playing his third test, had creative roles in an early try for flanker Liam Squire and in winger Rieko Ioane's double.\n\nMidfielder Ryan Crotty had his first try after forwards Joe Moody and Brodie Retallick broke the Australian defense, Sonny Bill Williams crashed over in the 34th, and Crotty scored his second try in the last minute of the first half.\n\nThe result was certain, and New Zealand took a major step toward retaining the Bledisloe Cup which it has held since 2003.\n\nIts grip on the match became more emphatic when McKenzie scored a brilliant try in the third minute of the second half, then winger Ben Smith added another from a break by Squire.\n\nNew Zealand seemed headed for an historic winning margin but the tide turned.\n\nThe Wallabies' pride demanded they grab a foothold somewhere, and they came back with tries to winger Curtis Rona on debut, centers Tevita Kuridrani and Kurtley Beale, who was playing his first test since the 2015 Rugby World Cup, and fullback Israel Folau.\n\nThe All Blacks might have surpassed 60 points with a late try to Beauden Barrett but the score was overruled by the television official.\n\n\"We just took our foot off the throat a bit,\" Read said. \"We'll take the positives and there's obviously things to learn from. It's not often you come here and put 50 points on the Wallabies.\"\n\nThe return match is next Saturday in Dunedin, and the Wallabies need to win in New Zealand for the first time since 2001 to keep the Bledisloe Cup series alive.\n\nCheika still had faith his side could do it. He said he wasn't going to make many changes.\n\n\"It comes down to a deep belief between players,\" he said. \"We've got to acknowledge what we did wrong first of all and then say, 'OK, we've got to fix that thing or those two things or whatever they might be,' and then go to it and do it.\n\n\"This is a roadblock in front of us, and it's going to knock us down but it's not going to stop us.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "10090876", "url": "http://www.centredaily.com/sports/article168176962.html", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "details": {}, "uri": "711988583", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://www.centredaily.com/static/images/centredaily/facebook.jpg", "timeCrawl": "17:45:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:45:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Rugby Championship: 8 tries for NZ in 54-34 win v Australia", "location": null, "categories": [], "time": "17:45:00", "source": {"uri": "centredaily.com", "title": "centredaily", "id": "11117"}, "date": "2017-08-19", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19"}

performance from the Pumas could prevent the Springboks from opening their Rugby Championship campaign on the highest note possible by beating Argentina 37-15 at a packed Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium on Saturday night.\n\nLeading 13-5 at the break, the Boks scored four tries against two but Argentina showed why they are not regarded as lightweights in world rugby any longer and pushed the Boks for long periods with their tenacity.\n\nThe moment everyone was waiting for arrived in the 76 minute when Curwin Bosch replaced Elton Jantjies at flyhalf who produced a faultless kicking performance.\n\nIt's probably grossly unfair that the award must go to a singular player because flank Siya Kolisi, flyhalf Elton Jantjies and both wingers - who scored their first tries at Test level alone - in romping to their highest-ever total against Australia.\n\nThe contest was over at halftime with the All Blacks leading 40-6 at the break after tryscoring doubles to Reiko Ioane and Ryan Crotty, further five-pointers to Liam Squire and Sonny Bill Williams and five conversions to Beauden Barrett.\n\nThe onslaught continued with the All Blacks' seventh and eighth tries in the opening minutes of the second half as the Wallabies trailed 54-6.\n\nA crowd of just 54,846 fans - the lowest-ever for a Bledisloe battle at ANZ Stadium - were witnessing one of the Wallabies' lowest-ever performances. home.\n\nThe two sides square off again next Saturday in Dunedin with Michael Cheika's demoralised troops needing to somehow conjure a first win across the Tasman since 2001 to keep the series alive "person", "id": "560661"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Henry Speight"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Speight", "type": "person", "id": "716938"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Bernard Foley"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "There was hope it would be the start of something big, the resuscitation of Australian rugby no less - a Wallabies-led recovery which would bring the game in this country back from a near death experience. But it turned out to be a sad, forlorn longing, crushed by the weight of 23 men in black.\n\nSome claimed there were cracks in the All Blacks' armour. Sex scandals, bugging dramas and even a spelling crisis, but the only cracks were in the Wallabies' defence.\n\nThe All Blacks out-scored the Wallabies eight tries to four in their 54-34 win, setting a new record for points against Australia in a game which produced the second highest combined number of points, 88, in a Tri Nations/Rugby Championship Test. All Blacks Winger Rieko Ioane and centre Ryan Crotty both collected doubles.\n\nInstead of lifting spirits, the Wallabies defeat just created more despair to go with the gloom of Australia's 0-26 win-loss record against Kiwi opposition in Super Rugby and the culling of the Western Force.\n\nAustralian rugby desperately needed a Wallabies win to arrest the alarming decline of the game. Yet no one truly thought they could win, certainly not the fans. A crowd of only 54,846 showed up and a lot of supporters were Kiwis or, say it quietly, dual citizens. The large number of black coats, jumpers and jackets darkened the mood.\n\nIt was the worst crowd for a Bledisloe Cup Test in Sydney since they started playing at the 2000 Olympic venue in Homebush, but it was slightly better than some feared it might be, which unthinkably, was sub-50,000.\n\nThe All Blacks led 40-6 at half-time, setting a record for the most number of points they have scored against the Wallabies in a first-half. Australian five-eighth Bernard Foley opened the scoring with a penalty goal in the fourth minute after the All Blacks failed to roll away from the tackled player in their 22.\n\nBut the All Blacks soon exploited a weakness in the Wallabies' short-side defence. Flanker Liam Squire scored the first try of the game in the ninth minute after finishing an attacking movement on the left hand side with Wallabies winger Henry Speight rushing out of the line in the midfield to create an overlap.\n\nFoley edged the Wallabies closer, 7-6, with another penalty goal in the 16th minute after the All Blacks collapsed a scrum. But the visitors then blew the game apart, scoring 33 unanswered points in the next 24 minutes.\n\nIoane scored his first try in the 17th minute in the left hand corner after getting around Wallabies fullback Israel Folau. He was over again three minutes later, scoring a classic All Blacks try off turnover ball. A pass from Wallabies captain Michael Hooper to halfback Will Genia went to ground and the ball was scooped up by Crotty, who put Ioane away.\n\nCrotty scored in the 24th minute. Five-eighth Beauden Barrett looped around lock Brodie Retallick and slipped a pass to Crotty. By this point the Wallabies had already missed 27 tackles. Sonny Bill Williams scored in the 33rd minute, crashing over between rugby league convert Curtis Rona and Speight.\n\nCrotty collected his double on the stroke of half-time after receiving a cut-out pass from halfback Aaron Smith and darting over. And All Blacks fullback Damian McKenzie scored his first Test try in the 42nd minute to effectively put an end to any chance of a Wallabies comeback win.\n\nAll Blacks winger Ben Smith scored in the 47th minute after taking an inside ball from Aaron Smith, while Rona, replacement centre Tevita Kuridrani, centre Kurtley Beale and Folau scored consolation tries for the Wallabies, but even that was too little too late.\n\nThe Wallabies now travel to Dunedin where they will try to level the series on Saturday night. "type": "wiki", "id": "1272826"}], "body": "Springboks winger Courtnall Skosan (L/11#) is mobbed by teammates as he celebrates scoring a try during the International Rugby Test match against Argentina August 19, 2017\n\nWingers Courtnall Skosan and Raymond Rhule scored their first Test tries as South Africa stretched a winning run to four Tests by defeating Argentina 37-15 Saturday in the Rugby Championship.\n\nSpringboks fly-half Elton Jantjies kicked 17 points at Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium in Port Elizabeth as the home team finished comfortable victors after leading 13-5 at half-time.\n\nThe triumph followed a 3-0 whitewash of France two months ago and continued a turnaround after a calendar-year record eight defeats in 12 Tests last season.\n\nArgentina were virtually always on the back foot, committing countless handling errors, conceding numerous penalties and fly-half Nicolas Sanchez had an off-day with his goal-kicking.\n\n\"We could not have asked for a better start to the Rugby Championship,\" said South Africa skipper and lock Eben Etzebeth.\n\n\"Our sincere thanks to the unbelievable support that we got here tonight,\" he added, referring to the almost-capacity crowd in the 46,000-seat stadium.\n\n\"I cannot wait for the return match next weekend -- we will start preparing tomorrow. We are really looking forward to next weekend.\n\n\"It is incredible how the boys play for each other. The culture in this team is amazing and it is great to be part of it.\"\n\nArgentina skipper and hooker Agustin Creevy said: \"I think South Africa played a great game, but were are fortunate to have another chance to beat them next weekend.\n\nSpringboks winger Raymond Rhule (L) breaks through the Argentinian defence during the International Rugby Championship Test match August 19, 2017\n\n\"Our ball from set pieces and the breakdown was very slow so we have to fix that problem quickly.\n\n\"We have great memories from last year of Salta, where we beat the Springboks, and I hope we can repeat that feat at the same ground next weekend.\n\n\"My team will try to use home advantage in our favour and we will try to gain from the support of our people.\"\n\nRelentless early pressure from South Africa finally paid off after 12 minutes when Jantjies slotted a penalty after flanker Tomas Lezana went off his feet at a ruck.\n\nJantjies doubled the lead on 20 minutes from another penalty with Lezana again the offender, this time caught offside by French referee Romain Poite.\n\nA six-point lead after 20 minutes was hardly the reward the Springboks deserved as they had kept the Pumas hemmed deep in their half on a cool, clear eastern Cape evening.\n\nIt took Argentina 27 minutes to reach the South African '22' and almost immediately Sanchez had a chance to score, but missed a kickable penalty attempt.\n\nHowever, five minutes later the South Americans did score when a grubber kick from centre Jan Serfontein was snapped up by full-back Joaquin Tuculet, who counterattacked.\n\nWinger Emiliano Boffelli carried forward the move and his clever kick ahead was snapped up by scrum-half Martin Landajo and he dotted down in the corner.\n\nSpringboks full-back Andries Coetzee (C) runs with the ball during the International Rugby Test match against Argentina August 19, 2017\n\nSanchez failed to convert, leaving South Africa with a 6-5 ahead that did not reflect their possession and territory dominance.\n\nSouth Africa finally scored a try after 37 minutes as Skosan collected an inside pass from Jantjies, shrugged off a tackle and went over between the posts.\n\nJantjies converted and South Africa left the field at half-time full value for a 13-5 advantage.\n\nSanchez and Jantjies exchanged second-half penalties before Rhule burst between two Pumas to score his first try, which was converted.\n\nSlick handling sent Boffelli over at the other end and substitute fly-half Juan Martin Hernandez converted to leave the South Americans trailing 23-15 with an hour gone.\n\nSouth Africa controlled the final quarter and forwards Siya Kolisi and substitute Pieter-Steph du Toit scored tries which Jantjies converted.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McMahon", "type": "person", "id": "1272256"}], "body": "Alex McLeod runs through all you need to know you need to know ahead of Saturday's Bledisloe Cup clash between the All Blacks and the Wallabies.\n\nThe 159th test match between New Zealand and Australia will take place this weekend in a match that doubles as the opening Rugby Championship and Bledisloe Cup fixture of 2017.\n\nIt will be the 72nd trans-Tasman meeting to be held in Sydney throughout the 114-year history the sides share with each other, with ANZ Stadium hosting the event for the 17th time.\n\nIn that time, both the All Blacks and the Wallabies have eight wins apiece at the 83,500-capacity venue, while the two nations shared the spoils in a 14-all draw in 2014.\n\nThe previous 21 opening Tri Nations/Rugby Championship encounters between the two teams have been an overhwelmingly successful fixture for the All Blacks, having emerged victorious 16 times to Australia's four.\n\nThat trend of starting quickly in Bledisloe Cup series has been a long-existing one for the New Zealanders, as since the Bledisloe Cup was first contested for back in 1932, the All Blacks have won 40 of the 56 series opening clashes against the Wallabies.\n\nThis statistic seems unlikely to change for the Australians given their recent results against both the All Blacks and in their June test series, as well as the performances of their Super Rugby franchises this year.\n\nLast year, the Wallabies did little to knock the All Blacks off their perch as the more dominant side of the two, losing the Bledisloe Cup series 3-0 following a 42-8 thrashing in Sydney, a 29-9 loss in Wellington, and a 37-10 defeat in Auckland.\n\nThe Wallabies' aggregate score of 27 points was the lowest total score any Australian side has posted in a three-match Bledisloe Cup series since 1972.\n\nTheir prospects of claiming a rare victory over the All Blacks since 2015 further diminished in the June test window earlier this year.\n\nTwo lacklustre performances against Fiji and Italy in Melbourne and Brisbane were compounded by a demoralising 24-19 loss to Scotland in Sydney, just their tenth loss to the Scots in their 90-year history.\n\nIn addition to the Wallabies' sub-par performances over the past year is the disappointing results posted by Australia's Super Rugby clubs this season, who went 26 matches without victory against Kiwi sides in 2017.\n\nThe Brumbies qualified for the playoffs as Australia's top side with 34 competition points from a 6-9 record. By contrast, the Blues finished at the bottom of the New Zealand conference with a better record (7-1-7) and more competition points (37) than the Canberra-based outfit.\n\nThe All Blacks' recent drawn series against the British and Irish Lions may not have done a lot to emphasise the perceived gulf in class between them and Australia, but all of the aforementioned contributing factors have most definitely not installed fear that the Wallabies will pose a threat against the All Blacks this weekend.\n\nPound for pound, the Wallabies have the individual talent at their disposal to challenge the All Blacks in this year's series, but the All Blacks' superior strength of squad depth, combined with the Wallabies' lack of confidence following such poor outcomes in recent results by Australian sides should see the All Blacks extend their prolonged tenure as Bledisloe Cup holders for a 15th year.\n\nSix changes have been made to the starting All Blacks side that drew with the British and Irish Lions in Auckland last month.\n\nFive of these changes have been made in the backline, with perhaps the most notable of these being the selection of Damian McKenzie at fullback.\n\nThe lightweight 22-year-old was electric for the Chiefs in Super Rugby, finshing near the top of many key attacking statistics at the conclusion of the season.\n\nHe was first in running metres (1,713), line breaks (22), tackle busts (89), second in runs (74), and fourth in offloads (31), all of which highlight his outstanding attacking capabilities.\n\nHe will be looking to prove the All Blacks selectors wrong after getting dropped from the Lions series to make way for fellow youngster Jordie Barrett.\n\nIt is the injured Barrett who he replaces at fullback, with vice-captain Ben Smith shifting to the right wing as he makes his return to the black jersey after suffering from vertigo during the Lions tour.\n\nSmith replaces Israel Dagg, who is being rested after getting through a massive workload with both the All Blacks and Super Rugby champion Crusaders over the past few months.\n\nThe other key change in All Blacks' starting side is the inclsuion of Highlanders' loose forward Liam Squire at blindside flanker ahead of veteran Jerome Kaino.\n\nSquire's selection suggests coach Steve Hansen and his assistants are beginning to assess potential candidates to fill the number six jersey once Kaino - who will be 36 years old at the 2019 World Cup - hangs his boots up.\n\nOther changes to the starting line up include Rieko Ioane returning from illness to take the left wing jersey back off the now ommitted Julian Savea, while Sonny Bill Williams and Ryan Crotty return from suspension and injury respectively to replace the midfield duo of Ngani Laumape and Anton Lienert-Brown.\n\nLienert-Brown is still likely to take the field on Saturday, as he has been named on the bench in the number 23 jersey in place of the departing Malakai Fekitoa.\n\nHe is one of four changes that have been made in the reserves, with Lima Sopoaga replacing France-bound Aaron Cruden as reserve first-five, Luke Romano taking the replacement lock spot ahead of fellow Crusader Scott Barrett, and youngster Ofa Tu'ungafasi earning the number 18 jersey in place of the departed Charlie Faumuina.\n\nMeanwhile, the Wallabies have made five changes to the starting XV that defeated Italy during the June test window.\n\nThe New Zealand-born Curtis Rona has been picked on the left wing to make his test debut in what could be regarded as the most surprising selection by coach Michael Cheika this week.\n\nHe is accompanied by Henry Speight on the right wing, with the two speedsters replacing Dane Haylett-Petty and Sefa Naivalu.\n\nA new midfield pairing has also been named to replace the injured Karmichael Hunt the Northampton-bound Rob Horne.\n\nKurtley Beale completes his return to Australian rugby from English club rugby after being named at second-five, while Samu Kerevi has recovered from injury to partner Beale in the midfield.\n\nThe lone change in the forward pack comes at number eight, with Sean McMahon taking the place of his Melbourne Rebels teammate Lopeti Timani, who drops to the bench in the number 20 jersey.\n\nTimani is one of five changes in the reserves, with Tom Robertson, Rob Simmons, Nick Phipps and Tevita Kuridrani all earning places on the bench after missing the Italian test.\n\nAll Blacks: 1. Joe Moody, 2. Codie Taylor, 3. Owen Franks, 4. Brodie Retallick, 5. Sam Whitelock, 6. Liam Squire, 7. Sam Cane, 8. Kieran Read (c), 9. Aaron Smith, 10. Beauden Barrett, 11. Rieko Ioane, 12. Sonny Bill Williams, 13. Ryan Crotty, 14. Ben Smith (vc), 15. Damian McKenzie\n\nReserves: 16. Nathan Harris, 17. Wyatt Crockett, 18. Ofa Tu'ungafasi, 19. Luke Romano, 20. Ardie Savea, 21. TJ Perenara, 22. Lima Sopoaga, 23. Anton Lienert-Brown\n\nWallabies: 1. Scott Sio, 2. Stephen Moore, 3. Allan Alaalatoa, 4. Rory Arnold, 5. Adam Coleman, 6. Ned Hanigan, 7. Michael Hooper (c), 8. Sean McMahon, 9. Will Genia, 10. Bernard Foley, 11. Curtis Rona, 12. Kurtley Beale, 13. Samu Kerevi, 14. Henry Speight, 15. Israel Folau\n\nReserves: 16. Tatafu Polota-Nau, 17. Tom Robertson, 18. Sekope Kepu, 19. Rob Simmons, 20. Sean McMahon, 21. Nick Phipps, 22. Reece Hodge, 23. Tevita Kuridrani\n\nThe TAB list the All Blacks as strong favourites to draw first blood this Bledisloe Cup series, with the current holders paying $1.09 for a victory in Sydney. In comparison, the Wallabies are paying an unfavourable $7.20 for an unlikely first up win.\n\nRieko Ioane is the favourite to score the first try of the match, paying $7.50. Israel Folau, Henry Speight and Curtis Rona are joint favourites to score the first try for the Wallabies, paying $15.\n\nPerhaps the best way to emphasise the perceived gulf in class between the All Blacks and Wallabies is that the TAB consider Ioane, Ben Smith, Damian McKenzie, Beauden Barrett, Sonny Bill Williams, Ryan Crotty and Kieran Read as either more or just as likely to score before any of the aforementioned Australians.\n\nThe Herald will be live blogging the game, and RadioSport will have live commentary. Sky TV will be showing the match live on Sky Sport 1 at 10pm.\n\nSouth Africa and Argentina will round out the opening weekend of the Rugby Championship tomorrow morning, with kick off at Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium in Port Elizabeth scheduled for 3.05am (NZT).\n\nThe Springboks will head into the clash as favourites, as they are playing in front of a home crowd and will look to continue on from their successful test series whitewash against France in June.\n\nHowever, since their inclusion in the Rugby Championship in 2012, the Pumas' best winning record is against the South Africans - a trend they will look to continue.\n\nSpringboks: 1. Tendai Mtwarira, 2. Malcolm Marx, 3. Coenie Oosthuizen, 4. Eben Etzebeth (c), 5. Franco Mostert, 6. Siya Kolisi, 7. Jaco Kriel, 8. Uzair Cassiem, 9. Ross Cronje, 10. Elton Jantjies, 11. Courtnall Skosan, 12. Jan Serfontein, 13. Jesse Kriel, 14. Raymond Rhule, 15. Andries Coetzee\n\nReserves: 16. Bongi Mbonambi, 17. Steven Kitshoff, 18. Trevor Nyakane, 19. Pieter-Steph du Toit, 20. Jean-Luc du Preez, 21. Francois Hougaard, 22. Curwin Bosch, 23. Damian de Allende\n\nPumas: 1. Nahuel Tetaz Chaparro, 2. Augustin Crrevy (c), 3. Enrique Pieretto, 4. Guido Petti Pagadiz\u00e1bal, 5. Tom\u00e1s Lavanini, 6. Pablo Matera, 7. Tomas Lezana, 8. Leonardo Senatore, 9. Martin Lendajo, 10. Nicolas Sanchez, 11. Emiliano Boffelli, 12. Jer\u00f3nimo de la Fuente, 13. Mat\u00edas Orlando, 14. Ramiro Moyano, 15. Joaquin Tuculet\n\nReserves: 16. Juli\u00e1n Montoya, 17. Lucas Noguera Paz, 18. Ramiro Herrera, 19. Marcos Kremer, 20. Javier Ortega Desio, 21. a question on whether Kaino, who was not picked in the match day 23, would be available for selection for the All Blacks' next match against Australia in Dunedin on Saturday.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Rugbyheaven Newsletter Rugbyheaven Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\n\"That's a pretty loaded question,\" Hansen said. \"We all know what the problem is, he's got stuff he needs to deal with so once he's dealt with that we'll make some decisions.\n\n\"There's been enough written about that already. It's a personal thing that he and his family have to deal with and there's no point us sitting here trying to talk about how he feels.\n\n\"I've got no show of telling what his headspace is. You put yourself in his shoes, what would yours be like?\"\n\nIn what has been a particularly difficult week for New Zealand rugby in the wake of the Kaino allegations and resurfacing of the Aaron Smith sex scandal, Hansen said there was no more motivation than normal before the All Blacks' 54-34 thumping of the Wallabies at ANZ Stadium.\n\n\"Rugby is always going to have moments where you're not happy with what's going on but ultimately it's all about Saturday isn't it?\" Hansen said. \"It's about winning the game and doing things right and doing things you can be proud of, so we've done that tonight.\n\n\"We did nothing different this week to what we normally do.\n\n\"Motivation's not about things like that. Motivation comes from players who want to be the best they possibly can be. It doesn't matter what sport you play ... motivation is internal.\"\n\nAsked what he thought of Smith's performance after being in the spotlight all week, Hansen replied: \"I thought he played really well\".\n\nMeanwhile, Hansen deflected a question in relation to a News Corp report revealing court documents that showed All Blacks team manager Darren Shand told police he believed Wallabies coach Michael Cheika may have been involved in the planting of a listening device in New Zealand's team hotel last year.\n\nShand's comments completely contradict what Hansen said on Thursday.\n\n\"We certainly haven't named them ... and we never will because we don't know who put it there,\" Hansen said during the week. \"I don't know where they feel the inference was because we certainly haven't blamed ... we don't know who put it there.\"\n\nOn Saturday, Hansen did not want to make comment, while an All Blacks media manager tried to change the topic of conversion.\n\n\"The bug case is over, isn't it?\" Hansen said.\n\nWith Stuff", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "10088530", "url": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christchurch", "label": {"eng": "Christchurch"}, "type": "loc", "id": "72814", "location": {"label": {"eng": "Christchurch"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "New Zealand"}, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football", "type": "wiki", "id": "302552"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rugby union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_union", "type": "wiki", "312214"}, {"score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Rugby league"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_league", "type": "wiki", "id": "317335"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "South Africa national
