"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_and_Irish_Lions", "type": "wiki", "id": "326436"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Australia national rugby union team"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_union_team", "type": "wiki", "id": "333908"}, {"score": 3, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire", "label": {"eng": "British Empire"}, "type": "loc", "id": "341235", "location": null}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New Zealand national rugby union team"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team", "type": "wiki", "id": "346371"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bledisloe Cup"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bledisloe_Cup", "type": "wiki", "id": "380187"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Australia national rugby league team"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_league_team", "type": "wiki", "id": "381947"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Test match (rugby union)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_match_(rugby_union)", "type": "wiki", "id": "396912"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "James Busby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Busby", "type": "person", "id": "399073"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New Zealand Rugby Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Rugby_Union", "type": "wiki", "id": "407266"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ranfurly Shield"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranfurly_Shield", "type": "wiki", "id": "431871"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Governor-General of New Zealand"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor-General_of_New_Zealand", "type": "wiki", "id": "432212"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Treaty of Waitangi"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi", "type": "wiki", "id": "432816"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Eden Park"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eden_Park", "type": "wiki", "id": "444559"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Dave Gallaher"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Gallaher", "type": "person", "id": "466381"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "World Rugby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Rugby", "type": "wiki", "id": "498026"}, {"score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Nicholas Shehadie"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicholas_Shehadie", "type": "person", "id": "829921"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Trevor Allan"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Allan", "type": "person", "id": "1006440"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Charles Bathurst, 1st Viscount Bledisloe"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Bathurst,_1st_Viscount_Bledisloe", "type": "person", "id": "1231600"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "David Brockhoff"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Brockhoff", "type": "person", "id": "1238752"}], "body": "This remains the most points scored in a Test between Australia and New Zealand. The match so enthralled the general public that the journalist Jane Fraser revealed to her readers that eastern suburbs matrons had taken to calling great love-making the equivalent of \"Bledisloe Cup sex.\"\n\nThere is an irony in the iconic name given to the trophy played for by Australia and New Zealand in Test rugby.\n\nThere is no evidence that Lord Bledisloe, the Governor-General of New Zealand between 1929 and 1935 and alleged donor of the Bledisloe Cup, knew one end of a rugby ball from the other or cared in any way at all about the Tests played under his nomenclature.\n\nWho was this Lord Bledisloe who has such an undeserved sporting immortality?\n\nWhen I worked at the Sydney Morning Herald, in the days when it had a remarkable library holding documents going back to 1842, I discovered in this archive a typewritten biography of Lord Bledisloe, The English Statesman, that was sent out to newspaper offices throughout the British Empire by the Whitehall press office in London, dated October 1929, to mark his New Zealand appointment:\n\n\"Charles Bathurst, barrister, politician, agriculturalist and First Baron BLEDISLOE, was born Sept. 1867, and educated at Sherborne, Eton and University College, Oxford. After leaving Oxford, he was called to the bar in 1894 and practised as a Chancery barrister and conveyancer for 16 years. In 1910 he was elected Conservative MP for S. Wilts and made a member of the Duchy of Lancaster ...\"\n\nThis biography was updated in March 1934 when Lord Bledisloe was coming to the end of his term as Governor-General:\n\n\"In November 1929, Lord Bledisloe was appointed Governor-General of New Zealand... His knowledge of and interest in agriculture made him the most popular Governor of the Dominion in many years. He did everything in his power to strengthen the Empire bond in New Zealand. The fact that every article he wore was made there from Dominion materials gave great satisfaction... In May, 1932, he and Lady Bledisloe presented to the people of New Zealand one of the country's most precious relics... a house built by James Busby... at the Bay of Islands, outside which the Treaty of Waitangi was signed in 1840...\"\n\nThere is no evidence that Lord Bledisloe, the alleged donor of the Bledisloe Cup, knew one end of a rugby ball from the other.\n\nThere was no reference in this official retrospective of Lord Bledisloe's term of office in New Zealand of the famous trophy he was supposed to have donated for competition between the national rugby teams of New Zealand and Australia.\n\nEnter now into this strange story Bruce Hewitt, a New Zealand-born journalist and rugby fanatic, who worked for the New Zealand Press Association in New Zealand and Australia during a distinguished career in the media.\n\nAn article Hewitt wrote for the Sun-Herald in 1988 gave an entirely different perspective on the so-called \"most popular Governor.\" Hewitt remembered Lord Bledisloe as a man, often at odds with journalists, \"who had little interest in football, and his outdoor activities were limited to farming and long-winded speech-making at country shows.\"\n\nLord Bledisloe was once photographed, Hewitt recalled, at the Canterbury Show at Christchurch. The next day the photograph of a beaming Lord Bledisloe was run in the Christchurch Times. The caption underneath the photograph described Lord Bledisloe \"as the prize-winning ram at the Canterbury Show.\"\n\nLord Bledisloe insisted that the sub who wrote the caption be dismissed.\n\nThis incident, wrote Hewitt, triggered Lord Bledisloe's \"long-running differences with the New Zealand press... To a generation of reporters he became 'Chattering Charlie,' and there were harsher names when his complaints led inevitably to sackings in those bleak, jobless, and depression days.\"\n\nAn official of Lord Bledisloe's stature who is offside with the national press is in clear need of a public relations gesture, or gestures, it seems to me, to persuade the public that he is a man of compassion and devotion to the New Zealand people.\n\nThe gift of Waitangi House, mentioned in the 1934 Whitehall press release, fitted this need. And so too did giving his name to a Test match competition between the rugby teams of Australia and New Zealand.\n\nAn observant reader will notice that the inference in the last sentence is that Lord Bledisloe did not actually donate the Bledisloe Cup, as popular memory indicates.\n\nBut he did allow his name to be used with the trophy, which is an important difference.\n\nThe fact is that there was no acknowledgement by Lord Bledisloe of any deep involvement or even interest in the trophy. There is no evidence, either, that Lord Bledisloe instigated the creation of the trophy.\n\nThere was no mention, as I have noted, in the official biography issued to the media at the end of his term of office in New Zealand about the Bledisloe Cup, either.\n\nWith the Bledisloe Cup Tests already being played and the large trophy on display at these matches while Lord Bledisloe was still in office, you would have thought that the trophy's creation would have been listed as one of his achievements in New Zealand.\n\nYears later, too, when Lord Bledisloe, now in his anecdotage and sounding like PG Wodehouse's Lord Emsworth with his passion for pigs, toured New Zealand and Australia in the 1950s, there is no mention in the numerous press articles of the time of his connection with the rugby trophy named after him.\n\nThe official version of his close involvement is given in Keith Quinn's The Encyclopedia of World Rugby:\n\n\"The Bledisloe Cup was presented in 1931 by Lord Bledisloe, then Governor-General of New Zealand, as a trophy to be played between the Test teams of Australia and New Zealand... The first game for the trophy was played at Eden Park in Auckland in 1931, New Zealand winning by 20-13. The game, played in front of Lord Bledisloe, was notable for the small crowd that turned out (nearly 15,000) and for the scoring of 14 points by the New Zealand fullback, Ron Bush of Otago...\"\n\nBut did Lord Bledisloe watch the match at Eden Park? The evidence is strong that he did not.\n\nGordon Slater in his monumental history, On the Ball: The Centennial Book of New Zealand Rugby, is adamant that Lord Bledisloe was not even in Auckland at the time: \"He was in Wellington to attend the commercial travellers' smoke concert, at which he told them that the world was topsy-turvy, particularly in the sphere of industry and commerce.\"\n\nThe 1931 match at Eden Park involved the first Australian side in 18 years to play a Test (according to the NZRU) in New Zealand. Public interest in the tour was lukewarm. The side had won three matches, lost four and drawn one in the lead-up to the Test.\n\nWe go back now to Gordon Slater:\n\n\"On the day before the game, it was announced from Wellington that the Governor-General had presented a cup for competition between New Zealand and Australian Rugby teams and that the first match for the trophy would be the Test at Auckland the following day. Mr S.S.M. Deans, president of the New Zealand Rugby Union, and T.C. Davis, manager of the Australian team, expressed appreciation of the offer. The design of the cup was to be decided upon later, but it would be symbolic of the two countries.\"\n\nNotice that the announcement was made from Wellington, not Auckland. This is another indicator that Lord Bledisloe remained in Wellington, despite the fact that New Zealand were playing Australia for a trophy that bore his name the next day in Auckland.\n\nThe four Tests against the British and Irish Lions in 1930 drew crowds of 27,000 at Dunedin, 30,000 at Christchurch, 40,000 at Eden Park in Auckland and 40,000 at Wellington. The problem for the NZRU was that Lions tours, like the successful Springboks tour of 1921, were once in a decade money-making events.\n\nThe Wallabies, now that the QRU had been re-established in 1929 after closing down during World War I, would be touring New Zealand every couple of years. But on the evidence of the poor crowds for the first tour of the Wallabies since before World War I, the NZRU decided that something had to be done to make the New Zealand-Australia rugby contests more popular.\n\nMy hunch is that the NZRU decided to enhance the Tests by giving them a sort of Ranfurly Shield makeover.\n\nIn 1901, the Governor of New Zealand, Lord Ranfurly, offered a challenge trophy to the NZRU to be competed for between NZ unions, on a one-off basis, with the holder playing at home unless deciding to take the shield on tour.\n\nBy the 1930s, and even today, the Ranfurly Shield, the storied 'Log of Wood,' had created an aura and a passion about it that meant that big crowds invariably attended shield challenges.\n\nAn equivalent of a Ranfurly Shield for New Zealand - Australian Test competition was put in place by the NZRU to create interest in the trans-Tasman rugby rivalry.\n\nGetting old 'Chattering Charlie' to agree to the concept, though, was easier than getting him to actually attend the first Bledisloe Cup Test.\n\nHeadlines in the sports section of the New Zealand Free Lance of 7 September 1949 summed up the anguish and shock of the New Zealand rugby community:\n\n\"AN ALL BLACK DAY IN RUGBY: TWO TEST DEFEATS. Penalties Give Springboks Win For Second Time, Australia Too Good For Uninspired Home Side\"\n\nOn the same day, separated by thousands of miles and a few hours in time, the All Blacks lost two Tests. Bad (and in New Zealand eyes, biased) refereeing was behind a loss by a touring New Zealand side to South Africa 9-3 (three penalty goals to one try). Incompetent administration and hubris was to blame for a 11-6 defeat of another New Zealand side at Wellington by a touring Australian side.\n\nWith 30 of the nation's best players touring South Africa, the NZRU was careless about the prestige of the All Blacks, and condescending of Australian rugby, in agreeing to a two-match Test series for the Bledisloe Cup.\n\nThere was an excuse, perhaps, for the carelessness. From 1931 up to 1949, 14 Bledisloe Cup Tests had been played. The Wallabies had won one and drawn one in 1934 to win their first home Bledisloe Cup series. In all, the Wallabies had lost 12 Tests, including all four played in New Zealand in the two-match series in 1936 and 1946.\n\nThe precedent, too, for playing a third-string side had been set in 1905 when New Zealand defeated Australia 14-3 at Dunedin while the famous 1905-06 All Blacks had already left the country on their epic tour of Britain and France.\n\nThe task of the third-string All Blacks in 1949 was made much harder by the fact the team for the first Test at Wellington was selected only the day before it ran on to the field. No coach was provided, either.\n\nThe All Blacks were outplayed by the Wallabies, who tailored their tactics to suit a chilly, blustery day. Trevor Allan, the Australian captain, won the toss and played with the wind. By half-time, the Wallabies were leading 11-0 after kicking for position when they had the ball.\n\nThe All Blacks' possession was spoilt, particularly at the lineout, by the 'impetuous' Wallaby flanker David Brockhoff and the greyhound-fast Col Windon launching themselves at the New Zealand number ten, legally, when the half-back was set to pass to him.\n\nThis relentless attack on the New Zealand pivot destroyed any cohesion the All Blacks might have mustered.\n\nYears later, the inimitable Brockhoff, who attracted calls of \"Off-Side Brockhoff!\" throughout the tour, summed up the havoc he and Windon had caused this way: \"We missiled them all day, never gave them a sniff.\"\n\nThe mayhem of the Brockhoff-Windon double act continued during the second Test at Eden Park, won comfortably by the Wallabies 16-9.\n\nThe victory secured Australia's first Bledisloe Cup series win in New Zealand.\n\n\"Brockhoff's spoiling and scavenging were reminiscent of Cliff Porter and Dave Gallaher at their best,\" RH Chester and NAC McMillan noted in their monumental history of All Blacks rugby Men in Black.\n\nThe Wallabies were able to dominate the lineouts, a rare achievement in this era, with Nick Shehadie, later Lord Mayor of Sydney and knighted for his civic achievements, and a brash young Rex Mossop applying the needed energy and grunt.\n\n\"Hi Dad, hi Mum, hi Kirk! We've beaten the bastards! You beauty!\"\n\nAt the end of the Test, an elated Mossop gave some indication of the uninhibited sports broadcaster he was to become after his distinguished rugby and rugby league career ended when he was asked by a radio reporter to send a cheerio call back to Australia. Without any hesitation, he grabbed the microphone and yelled out: \"Hi Dad, hi Mum, hi Kirk! We've beaten the bastards! You beauty!\"\n\nThere was one further humiliation in store for New Zealand rugby in a year when the All Blacks lost four Tests to the Springboks, and two more and the Bledisloe Cup to the Wallabies.\n\nPeter Jenkins, in his magisterial history Wallaby Gold, tells the story of how the tour manager of the 1949 Wallabies, Bill Cerutti, rubbed salt into New Zealand rugby's wounds:\n\n\"The All Blacks heading home from South Africa docked in Sydney en route to New Zealand. When they arrived, Cerutti was down at the wharf, brandishing the Bledisloe Cup. It was the first time Australia had won the silverware in 15 years. 'Here it is,' he shouted to the New Zealanders. 'We've got it now.'\"\n\nTwo years later, the Bledisloe Cup was taken back by the All Blacks in a three-Test series played in Australia with the All Blacks, determined on revenge, winning all three Tests.\n\nFrom 1951 to 1978, the All Blacks won 26 Bledisloe Cup Tests and all 12 series. The Wallabies won only five Tests and two were drawn.\n\nThe effect of this one-sided contest was the interest in the trophy itself diminished.\n\nThe All Blacks' tradition, for instance, of filling the huge trophy to the brim with 26 jugs of beer and skulling the lot after a winning series was forgotten, only to be revived decades later in the professional era.\n\nThe real clincher in how unimportant the Bledisloe Cup had become in the memory of the rugby community is that it actually disappeared for a number of years. Apparently no-one, either in New Zealand or Australia, was aware of this disappearance, nor was anyone concerned about it.\n\nBruce Hewitt was given the job of finding the Cup as part of his NZPA duties in Australia. After an intensive investigation, he was able to report back with good news:\n\n\"The Bledisloe Cup has turned up eventually unharmed under a great deal of dusty cardboard cut-outs of Maori huts and Mount Cooks in the back storerooms of the old New Zealand Government Tourist Bureau in Temple Court, Melbourne, where it had evidently been taken for display purposes and forgotten.\"", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "9766663", "url": "http://www.theroar.com.au/2017/08/18/spiro-all-blacked-out-inspiring-stories-of-bledisloe-cup-glory-and-defeat/", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "details": {}, "uri": "711084158", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://cdn0.theroar.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/All-Blacks-celebrate-2000-bledisloe-cup.jpg", "timeCrawl": "19:52:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:33:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "All Blacked-out! They're desperate, he said.\n\nTell us something we don't know. It is now 14 years since Australia surrendered the precious symbol of trans-Tasman supremacy. As it happens, Richie McCaw was playing in his 14th Test for the All Blacks when he stuffed up Australia for the first but by no means last time, tackling a try-bound Steve Larkham on a wet night in Auckland, August 16, 2003. The two players slid into the base of the posts at Eden Park which would have been a try, except that the ball was held in Larkham right arm -- and it was his left arm that touched the upright. Needless to say, McCaw got to his feet and won the penalty. Australia lost that Test 21-17. "id": "444559"}], "body": "It emerged yesterday that Australian coach Michael Cheika confronted Steve Hansen over the so-called Spygate scandal earlier this year.\n\nTension has ran high between the two camps since the All Blacks found a listening device in the team room of their Sydney hotel ahead of last year's opening Bledisloe Cup clash.\n\nThe discovery sparked a police investigation which led to the All Blacks' security contractor, Adrian Gard, being charged with public mischief. A verdict in the case is expected before Saturday's test and regardless of the outcome, there is going to be a further heavy impact on the relationship between the two nations.\n\nSince the New Zealand Herald broke the story almost exactly a year ago, the Australian Rugby Union has made it clear that they feel the Wallabies were implicated by New Zealand as the most likely guilty party.\n\nThe Australians have used the timing of the story breaking - on the day of the first Bledisloe test - as their justification to cast themselves as the accused.\n\nIt's a stance that has infuriated the New Zealand Rugby Union who have been careful in all of their public comments to not make allegations of blame or insinuate or speculate who might have planted the device.\n\nBut following the Wallabies 37-12 defeat at Eden Park last year - their fourth consecutive loss to the All Blacks - Cheika launched into an extraordinary tirade.\n\n\"I would say they caught me a bit offside with the accusation that we tried to bug them,\" said Cheika when he was asked whether his and the Wallabies' relationship had turned septic with the All Blacks.\n\n\"Really? Hello? Honestly? They had that the whole week..? That showed a lack of respect. I wouldn't be smart enough to get that sort of stuff organised. I am too busy working on my own thing.\"\n\nThe sense of injustice and resentment simmering within the Wallaby camp didn't reside that night at Eden Park and Hansen confirmed that Cheika sought him out in May when the two men were in Tokyo to see the draw being made for the 2019 World Cup.\n\n\"I don't know if he confronted me,\" said Hansen.\n\n\"We had a chat in Japan and I made it clear to him that we didn't highlight [the Wallabies as a guilty party]. I said to him there are only x amount of people who would take that opportunity [to plant a bug] and whether we would like it or not, if you [Cheika] found a bug in your [Wallabies] team room, we [All Blacks] would be one of those. So we haven't named them as that and we never will because we don't know who put it there.\n\n\"I don't know where they feel the inference was because we haven't said it. We don't know who put it there and we said at the time and that hasn't changed. We can't help how they feel.\"\n\nAn already difficult and tense relationship between the two sides now sits on the cusp of yet more ill-will and bad blood developing, depending on the verdict in the Gard case.\n\nA guilty verdict will incense the All Blacks while exoneration will effectively leave the mystery unsolved and the Australians thinking the cloud of suspicion they believe is hovering for them, lingering for longer.\n\nHansen said that he was keeping an eye on the ongoing Gard case.\n\n\"Obviously we are watching with interest. Championship and Bledisoe Cup Test match against the Australian Wallabies \u00a9 AFP / WILLIAM WEST\n\nSYDNEY, Australia, Aug 18 - The All Blacks identified their lineout as a weak point against the British and Irish Lions and plan a big fix against the Wallabies, lock Brodie Retallick said Friday.\n\nThe usually rock-solid set piece was disrupted by the Lions in last month's drawn series, and Retallick said the Kiwi pack was determined to find a cure in Saturday's Rugby Championship opener in Sydney.\n\n\"I think we had our worst series in terms of lineouts that we've had in a number of years, so that's obviously something that we've looked at this week,\" Retallick told reporters.\n\n\"There was a little bit of communication breakdown (against the Lions).\n\n\"We just didn't know our roles, so it's been a huge focus of getting together and getting back to the standard we know we're capable of, and our timing.\n\n\"As a forward pack we've got high expectations of ourselves to get the lineout right. It's certainly an area that's highly contested these days, so we're always trying to put pressure on the opposition.\"\n\nRetallick, who forms one of rugby's most feared locking partnerships with Sam Whitelock, expects a tough battle with the Australian jumpers Adam Coleman and Rory Arnold.\n\n\"We have got some pretty tall timber and some athletes there, but in saying that the Australians have come a long way,\" he said.\n\nThe 64-cap Retallick said he was respectful of Coleman, who has emerged as the Wallabies' lineout leader in the past 12 months.\n\n\"In the lineout, and his ball-carrying, he's very physical, he runs some great lines,\" he said.\n\n\"So I've got huge respect for Adam as a lock and as a forward, and I think over the last couple of seasons he's come a long way.\"\n\nWhile strong favourites to retain the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup for a 15th straight year, the All Blacks are wary of an ambush in Sydney.\n\nThe Wallabies have only won three of their past "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samu_Kerevi", "type": "person", "id": "1273399"}], "body": "For the second straight year the Wallabies were humiliated in front of their home fans, as the All Blacks racked up a record 40 first half points to set up their 54-34 win at ANZ Stadium on Saturday night.\n\nThe margin could have been bigger had the All Blacks not shut up shop midway through the second half, which allowed the Wallabies to add some respectability to the scoreboard by notching four tries.\n\nBut the 54,846 fans that showed up -- down from 65,328 last year -- witnessed another inept overall performance, which will place further strain on an already fed up rugby community.\n\nLIVE stream the Bledisloe Cup and Rugby Championship on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week Foxtel Now trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW >\n\nThe Wallabies conceded a point a minute in the first half and missed a staggering 35 tackles.\n\nBy the end of the match that number had extended to 48.\n\nBut, speaking at the post-match press conference, the 2015 World Rugby coach of the year said he had no issues with Grey's defensive structures.\n\n\"100 per cent, 100 per cent,\" Cheika said of the faith he held in Grey.\n\nYet the Wallabies were made to look like bind bats in defence throughout the first 60 minutes.\n\nReturning outside centre Samu Kerevi -- playing his first match in more than two months because of injury -- was brutally exposed.\n\nKerevi looked lost in defence, as the All Blacks' midfield sensed uncertainty and targeted him ruthlessly.\n\nFullback Israel Folau was also shown up in defence, with All Blacks winger Rieko Ioane making the Australian poster boy look silly by skinning him to score the visitors' second try.\n\nCheika refused to blame his side's character and instead said the Wallabies were guilty of not trusting their instincts.\n\n\"It's not attitude,\" Cheika said.\n\n\"I think it's maybe just that little bit of doubt creeps in.\n\n\"When something goes against you early, we've been preparing a certain way and it creeps in a little bit of doubt -- will I go or will I hedge? -- and that causes some of the problems.\"\n\nThe Wallabies went into the match with a clear emphasis of trying to score more points against the back-to-back world champions after managing just two tries in three matches during last year's Bledisloe Cup.\n\nKerevi, one of Super Rugby's most damaging ball runners, was selected alongside the returning Kurtley Beale to form the Wallabies' 10th midfield combination since the 2015 Rugby World Cup.\n\nSean McMahon was also selected in the back-row to offer some punch to the pack.\n\nBut the decision ultimately backfired, as the All Blacks picked apart the Wallabies' defensive system.\n\nCheika admitted they couldn't just rely on playing attacking rugby as they prepare for the rematch in Dunedin next Saturday.\n\n\"With the team that we've got, the points should be coming,\" Cheika said.\n\n\"We've got an attacking type of team, so we should be scoring points.\n\n\"Everyone understands what we've got to do to rectify that next week, both mentally and then on the training paddock.\"\n\nThe eight tries to four thrashing came after the Wallabies, for the second year straight, had a month to prepare for the match.\n\nThe All Blacks had considerably less time -- with four Super Rugby franchises involved in the finals -- but managed to play a warm-up match.\n\nBut Cheika said the Wallabies' preparation couldn't have been better, despite admitting that a lack of match practice can hurt.\n\n\"I think we had the right preparation, no doubt,\" he said.\n\n\"Obviously not playing a lot of footy, that leaves you out a little bit missing the games.\n\n\"One of the big things for us when we get into that situation and we've seen it in '15 and '16 is the longer we're together and playing footy, the better we're starting to get together, especially the combinations that we have.\n\n\"That still doesn't help us with anything about this game.\n\n\"You still feel just as bad obviously, but I know that we will improve and we've got to do some quick improving for the next game.\n\n\"We want to keep the series alive.\"\n\nThe Wallabies fly to Christchurch on Sunday to begin their preparations.\n\nAnd despite the heavy defeat, Cheika said he'd be hesitant to make many changes.\n\n\"I don't think that there's going to be a lot of changes,\" he said. in 2016 and a 14-year Bledisloe blackout for the Wallabies.\n\nThe doom and gloom has led to slow ticket sales and forecasts of barely 50,000 spectators fronting up for Saturday night's Rugby Championship opener in Sydney.\n\nThe record low Bledisloe attendance for ANZ Stadium is 65,238 that endured last year's demoralising 42-8 loss for the Wallabies, while the average crowd since the reconfiguration of the Olympic venue in 2001 is 76,219.\n\nA roll-up of less than 54,937 on Saturday would be less than half of the world-record rugby crowd of 109,874 that witnessed the so-called "Michael Lynagh angrily hit out at the Australia side following their abject first-half performance in the 54-34 defeat by New Zealand, in which they shipped 40 points before the break in what was a record score for the All Blacks.\n\nThe reigning world champions, who drew the recent series with the British and Irish Lions 1-1, scored six tries before half-time, with both Reiko Ioane and Ryan Crotty dotting down twice along with Liam Squire and the returning Sonny Bill Williams - back from his four-game ban for his shoulder charge on Anthony Watson six weeks ago.\n\nThe Wallabies had just two Bernard Foley penalties to show for their efforts, meaning they trailed by an enormous 34 points at the break, the most in their history of facing the All Blacks, and although it would get better in the second half as Michael Cheika's side scored four tries in the second-half, former Australia fly-half Lynagh cut loose on the side.\n\n\"I can't overestimate how angry I am at seeing an Australian team who have skills that are non-existent,\" he said as part of Sky Sports' broadcast of the Rugby Championship opener.\n\nNew Wallabies captain Michael Hooper tried to play down the devastating result, which was completed by further tries for full-back Damian McKenzie and wing Ben Smith, and he instead wanted to gloss over the poor start to focus on Australia's results.\n\nRead more All Blacks rack up record score against Australia to make flying start\n\nCurtis Rona, Tevita Kuridrani, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau all scored for the home side, with Foley converting all Hooper. \"Being 50 points behind, you start to throw everything we had, I'm so happy with that.\"\n\nHowever, despite witnessing his side score the most points they've ever achieved against their just worked for us. Irish Lions and plan a big fix against the Wallabies, lock Brodie Retallick said Friday.\n\nThe usually rock-solid set piece was disrupted by the Lions in last month's drawn series, and Retallick said the Kiwi pack was determined to find a cure in Saturday's Rugby Championship opener in Sydney.\n\n\"I think we had our worst series in terms of lineouts that we've had in a number of years, so that's obviously something that we've looked at this week,\" Retallick told reporters.\n\n\"There was a little bit of a communication breakdown (against the Lions). We just didn't know our roles, so it's been a huge focus of getting together and getting back to the standard we know we're capable of, and our timing.\n\n\"As a forward pack we've got high expectations of ourselves to get the lineout right. It's certainly an area that's highly contested these days, so we're always trying to put pressure on the opposition.\"\n\nRetallick, who forms one of rugby's most feared locking partnerships with Sam Whitelock, expects a tough battle with the Australian jumpers Adam Coleman and Rory Arnold.\n\n\"We have got some pretty tall timber and some athletes there, but in saying that the Australians have come a long way,\" he said.\n\nThe 64-cap Retallick said he was respectful of Coleman, who has emerged as the Wallabies' lineout leader in the past 12 months.\n\n\"In the lineout, and his ball-carrying, he's very physical, he runs some great lines,\" he said.\n\n\"So I've got huge respect for Adam as a lock and as a forward, and I think over the last couple of seasons he's come a long way.\"\n\n\"Outside of the World Cup this is the most special trophy\" - Kieran Read talks about the significance of the #BledisloeCup.#AUSvNZL pic.twitter.com/FnocD5sHue\n\n-- All Blacks (@AllBlacks) August 18, 2017\n\nWhile strong favourites to retain the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup for a 15th straight year, the All Blacks are wary of an ambush in Sydney.\n\nThe Wallabies have only won three of their past 29 Tests against New Zealand, and Australian sides performed poorly in this year's Super Rugby competition.\n\nBut All Blacks coach Steve Hansen said the Wallabies command respect.\n\n\"They've got a lot of talent and they've had a great preparation,\" Hansen said. \"While (Super Rugby) franchise fans weren't probably over-excited about the fact that they got knocked out early and would rather have seen them play right through to the final and have less preparation time, those two things make them a dangerous beast.\n\n\"The third thing that makes the really dangerous is their desire to try to help Australian rugby and at the moment it has a bit of a cloud over it and they haven't won the Bledisloe in a long time. Australia has had a month to work together to try and create stuff and do things and they come up with that in the first 40? Very, very disappointing.\"\n\nCheika conceded Australia's defence was not at the standard of an international team.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"It was pretty plain to see that our defence wasn't good enough at all,\" Cheika said. \"With adherence to the way we want to defend, plus also the tackling in itself, it's got to be better. It's not the level you can be at [at] all in any game, let alone a game against them.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Rugbyheaven Newsletter Rugbyheaven Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\n\"It's not attitude, it's just maybe that little bit of doubt creeps in.\n\n\"There's no one-two step process for that type of stuff, that comes down to a deep belief between players. You have to acknowledge what you did wrong first of all and then say, 'OK, we've got to fix those things and go and do it'. This group of players here, they've got a very strong connection.\"\n\nGrey, who is in charge of the defence portfolio, has been under pressure this year at the Waratahs after they recorded their worst year on record from a defensive viewpoint.\n\nFrom four Tests this year, the Wallabies have conceded 132 points - an average of 33 per game.\n\nAsked whether Grey had his support, Cheika replied: \"100 per cent\".\n\nI can't overestimate how angry I am at seeing an Australian team have skills that are non-existent.\n\nMichael Lynagh\n\nLynagh also took a swipe at Wallabies captain Michael Hooper and Nick Phipps in the wash-up.\n\n\"The thing that lingers with me is the first half, how poor that was,\" Lynagh said. \"Michael Hooper there seemed pretty content with the second half and that we scored a few tries. We still lost by 20 points at the end of the day and at half-time we were 40 points down.\n\n\"That's an international halfback Nick Phipps; passing one ball to his right and it goes above a bloke's head. It was just so poor.\n\n\"The simple skills of passing and tackling were non-existent in the first half and that's very worrying.\"\n\nCheika said he didn't expect there to be major changes ahead of Australia's next assignment in Dunedin on Saturday but rather a change in attitude.\n\n\"The change has to be more about believing in ourselves to make the hits when we need to,\" Cheika said. \"You still feel just as bad but I know we'll improve and we've got to do some quick improving around for the next game. We want to keep the series alive.\n\n\"We had the right preparation no doubt and obviously not playing a lot of footy that leaves you out a little bit missing the [Super Rugby] games. That's as good as we could have had it. It comes down to bringing that into the game.\"\n\nHooper added: \"As Michael said, our defence just wasn't up to scratch and there was a bit of an unravelling there for a bit. display of running rugby to demolish Australia 54-34 in the Rugby Championship opener yesterday.\n\nThe world champions extinguished any chance of an upset with three tries in seven first-half minutes and sliced through the home defense almost at will in the first 50 minutes to start their title defense with a bonus-point win.\n\nLiam Squire, Sonny Bill Williams, Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith also scored tries as the All Blacks brushed off the disappointment of the drawn British and Irish Lions series and a string of off-field distractions.\n\nThe Wallabies scored tries through debutant winger Curtis Rona, replacement back Tevita Kuridrani, center Kurtley Beale and fullback Israel Folau, but they came in the second half once the game was already beyond them.\n\n\"It was pretty surreal that first half to be honest. We came here to play our game and it really came off. It was a pretty awesome first half,\" New Zealand captain Kieran Read said.\n\n\"It came about by the doing the simple things. We carried really hard and exploited a few gaps out wide,\" he said.\n\nThe Wallabies face the All Blacks in Dunedin again next week and on this evidence their prospects of winning the remaining two Bledisloe Cup Tests to reclaim the trophy for the first time since 2002 must be rated as extremely remote.\n\n\"It is not the start we would have hoped for,\" Australia captain Michael Hooper said. \"Being 50 points behind, you start to throw everything we had, I'm so happy with that.\"\n\nLooking to dispel some of the gloom hanging over the Australian game, the Wallabies put together some sharp phases with their first possession and were rewarded with flyhalf Bernard Foley's penalty in the third minute.\n\nHowever, from then on it was one-way traffic in the first half with quick hands down the line sending Squire over in the 10th minute and the three-try burst from the 18th minute silencing what noise was coming from the home supporters.\n\nWinger Ioane scored the first two, beating a badly positioned Folau on the outside to race away for the second.\n\nFlyhalf Beauden Barrett's short pass sent Crotty in for the fourth try and his center partner Williams, returning after a four-match ban for his red card in the Lions series, stormed across for the fifth.\n\nCrotty still had time before the interval to claim his second after more poor tackling in the Wallabies midfield to give the visitors a 40-6 lead at the break.\n\nIt was more of the same after the restart with fullback McKenzie, playing his third Test, getting reward for his thrilling running and winger Ben Smith giving the All Blacks a 54-6 lead after 48 minutes.\n\nFacing their biggest ever Test defeat full in the face, the Wallabies rallied with the four unanswered tries to give the majority of the crowd of 54,846 something to cheer and secure a bonus point.\n\nThe All Blacks could have had a ninth try three minutes from time when Barrett charged down a Foley defensive kick, only for the video "person", "id": "370784"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Bledisloe Cup"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bledisloe_Cup", "type": "wiki", "id": "380187"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Kieran Read"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kieran_Read", "type": "person", "id": "432870"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jerome Kaino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Kaino", "type": "person", "id": "434172"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Bernard Foley"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "A strange week in Sydney has been followed by a strange test, one in which the All Blacks had all but sewn up at halftime only to see the Wallabies score four unanswered tries to give them something approaching a scare.\n\nThe first-half performance by the All Blacks was what they desperately needed in order to change the narrative after a bizarre week off the field thanks to the Aaron Smith and Jerome Kaino revelations, but while they were almost completely dominant before the break, afterwards it was a different matter entirely.\n\nThe Wallabies' fourth try - to Israel Folau - looked deeply suspicious. The All Blacks will believe either a forward pass from Bernard Foley or Folau's touching the ball in an offside position should have ruled it out, but referee Wayne Barnes allowed it and the home side had what they desperately needed - hope. Hope not for a victory in this match but hope nevertheless.\n\nA proper thrashing would have been a disaster for them, but they may just have redeemed themselves here, strange as it may sound with the All Blacks running up more than 50 points in a 54-34 victory.\n\nThe hosts, teetering following their Super Rugby shambles this year and a governing body in disarray, were in a desperate state at halftime when they trudged off 40-6 down.\n\nThe All Blacks, relishing the dry ground and fine conditions here after a wintry slog in June and July at home against the British and Irish Lions, had too many threats, too many ideas and too much desire.\n\nSignificantly, they had too much pace as well, with Rieko Ioane, Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith causing them fits. Wallabies assistant coach Mick Byrne, with the All Blacks for 11 years, predicted a frenetic match in terms of ball movement and it was, with either the All Blacks or the Wallabies in ascendancy. It was one of those matches.\n\nIt was difficult to pick the best try in a match which initially ran like an All Blacks' highlights reel, but Ben Smith's in the second half following Liam Squire's destructive run and Aaron Smith's inside pass must have been up there.\n\nThat try took the All Blacks to their highest score against Australia, beating the 50-21 they put on the Wallabies in this city in 2003, but Cheika's side weren't ready to give up and in showing their fighting spirit they may have just breathed a little life back into the Bledisloe Cup.\n\nSquire, running with freedom on the sidelines alongside skipper Kieran Read, should have the inside running over Kaino next weekend and his try - the All Blacks' first of eight - was a beauty. Fullback McKenzie, in his third test, should feel pretty satisfied too.\n\nAfter a week in which Spygate failed to reach a resolution and which has probably brought rugby relations between the two nations to a new low, there was ill feeling between the two sides, with Bernard Foley having a running battle with Sonny Bill Williams. And there will be bruises for both too.\n\nProp Wyatt Crockett went off with concussion - no head injury assessment required - and he must be a doubt for the return match next weekend.\n\nThe All Blacks, with a six wins in a row over their close rivals now, have one hand on the Bledisloe. Africa remain unbeaten in 2017 after they beat Argentina 37-15 in their Rugby Championship opener in Port Elizabeth on Saturday.\n\nTries from Courtnall Skosan, Raymond Rhule, Siya Kolisi and Pieter-Steph du Toit gave the Boks a winning start to the southern hemisphere campaign which comes on the back of their 3-0 whitewash of France in June.\n\nAllister Coetzee's side were dominant up front, and set the tempo of the match, but were unable to register a try-bonus point as the All Blacks ended the first round at the top of the Rugby Championship table following their 54-34 win over Australia in Sydney earlier in the day.\n\nThere were several good individual performances from the home side, including that of Kolisi, Jaco Kriel and Malcolm Marx, as the Boks now turn their attention to the second round where they travel to Argentina to take on the Pumas once more.\n\nA 12th-minute penalty from Elton Jantjies opened the scoring for the Boks in Port Elizabeth, and the hosts were almost in for their first try shortly thereafter.\n\nJust as Jaco Kriel was about to dot down referee Romain Poite called play back for a knock-on, however replays showed it was an incorrect call as the ball had come off an Argentine hand.\n\nA let-off for the Pumas but there was no such luck when they strayed offside during a threatening Springbok attack and Jantjies stepped up to put his side 6-0 ahead at the close of the first quarter. Nicholas Sanchez had an opportunity to reduce the lead when he lined up a shot at goal following a high tackle, but he sent his effort wide.\n\nArgentina vs South Africa\n\nAugust 26, 2017, 6:00pm\n\nLive on\n\nGet Sky Sports Get a Sky Sports pass\n\nArgentina then scored the try of the game from a counter-attack that started deep in their own half. break.\n\nThe fly-halves then traded penalties early in the second half before Rhule was put into space and straightened his line to crash over for the first try of the second half.\n\nWhen Boffelli after Jan Serfontein's attempted grubber kick was scooped up and Landajo sent clear to dot down.\n\nBut a moment of magic by Skosan just before halftime, coupled with some weak Argentine defence, Wallabies.\n\nThe doom and gloom has led to slow ticket sales and forecasts of barely 50,000 spectators fronting up for Saturday night's Rugby Championship opener in Sydney.\n\nThe record low Bledisloe attendance for ANZ Stadium is 65,238 that endured last year's demoralising 42-8 loss for the Wallabies, while the average crowd since the reconfiguration of the Olympic venue in 2001 is 76,219.\n\nA roll-up of less than 54,937 on Saturday would be less than half of the world-record rugby crowd of 109,874 that witnessed the so-called match of the century in 2000 when the All Blacks denied the Wallabies 39-35 in a thriller, after leading 24-0 in just nine minutes.\n\n\"For us as players, it's a big part for us to really get up when we see a lot of our fans and supporters turn series in terms of lineouts that we've had in a number of years, so that's obviously something that we've looked at this week,\" Retallick told reporters.\n\n\"There was a little bit of communication five-Test losing run against the world champions if they are to retain a realistic hope of winning back the trans-Tasman Bledisloe Cup for the first time in 15 years.\n\nCoach Michael Cheika wants his Wallabies to apply pressure to the All Blacks, as the British and Irish Lions did in their recent drawn series, in a bid to produce a boil over at Sydney's Olympic stadium on Saturday.\n\nHooper is expecting the All Blacks to hit the ground running to put the home team under pressure, and said it was important for his team-mates to hang in there.\n\n\"They are really good at that 60-minute mark of that continued pressure,\" Hooper told reporters.\n\n\"They know their roles really well, and that's their bench included.\n\n\"Our bench hasn't seen the enthusiasm in the last couple of games that the enthusiasm, and some really nice skill-set and experience on the bench to close out a game.\"\n\nHooper knows the importance of a first-up win at home. The Wallabies last won a Bledisloe Cup opener in 2015, a 27-19 victory after a 12-12 draw in the previous year.\n\nThe All Blacks have a relatively low 58.33 percent winning record at the Sydney venue but since losing back-to-back encounters in 2007 and 2008, the world champions have won six of the last eight.\n\n\"We do have the benefit of having two in Australia this year, so the one in Brisbane will be nice at the end,\" Hooper said.\n\n\"This group's come together this year to do something and what's wrong with a dream? What's wrong with a goal that everyone here wants to achieve?\n\n\"There's nothing wrong with it and that's what we should be aspiring to and wanting so everyone in our change-room has that mentality.\"\n\nThe Wallabies travel to Dunedin next week for game two, having never won a series after dropping the first match at home.\n\nThe last time Australia won a trans-Tasman Test in New Zealand was in 2001.\n\nThe Wallabies intend to attack the All Blacks through their classy 10-12-15 combination of Super Rugby's Waratahs trio Bernard Foley, Kurtley Beale and Israel Folau - together for the first time at international level.\n\n\"Our challenge is to hang on to it. If we're going to run the ball, hang on to it and back our skills because the quality of work these guys have done,\" Wallabies skills coach Mick Byrne said.\n\n\"I think you're going to see a pretty frenetic game tomorrow night.\"\n\nThe Wallabies had a shock home loss to Scotland in June and are coming off a dreadful Super Rugby season where Australian sides were 0-26 against Kiwi opposition.\n\nA season of problems on and off the pitch culminated with the contentious axing of Perth's Force last week.\n\nThere are three Force players - Adam Coleman, debutant Curtis Rona and Tatafu Polota-Nau - in the match-day Wallabies squad.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "9857378", "url": "http://www.sport24.co.za/Rugby/RugbyChampionship/wallabies-plan-to-stay-the-pace-with-all-blacks-20170818", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "details": {}, "uri": "711347839", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://cdn.24.co.za/files/Cms/General/d/2002/fa749432732e4ad095ea76c57f5c412c.gif", "timeCrawl": "09:04:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:04:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Wallabies plan to stay the pace with All Blacks", "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Games", "label": "dmoz/Games", "id": 49}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Recreation", "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Recreation", "id": 51}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Browser_Based", "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Browser Based", "id": 52}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Games/Roleplaying/Genres", "label": "dmoz/Games/Roleplaying/Genres", "id": 713}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Games/Board_Games/Abstract", "label": "dmoz/Games/Board Games/Abstract", "id": 751}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "id": 757}], "time": "09:04:00", "source": {"uri": "sport24.co.za", "title": "SPORT24", "id": "976"}, "date": "2017-08-18", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18"}

during their rugby union test match in Sydney\n\n(AP)\n\nRieko Ioane and Ryan Crotty both crossed twice as New Zealand ran in eight tries in a brilliant display of running rugby to demolish Australia 54-34 in the Rugby Championship opener on Saturday.\n\nThe world champions extinguished any chance of an upset with three tries in seven first-half minutes and sliced through the home defence almost at will in the opening 50 to start their title defence with a bonus-point win.\n\nLiam Squire, Sonny Bill Williams, Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith also scored tries as the All Blacks brushed off the disappointment of the drawn British and Irish Lions series and a string of off-field distractions.\n\nThe Wallabies scored tries through debutant winger Curtis Rona, replacement back Tevita Kuridrani, centre Kurtley Beale and fullback Israel Folau but they came in the second half once the game was already beyond them.\n\n\"It was pretty surreal that first half to be honest. We came here to play our game and it really came off. It was a pretty awesome first half,\" New Zealand captain Kieran Read said.\n\n\"It came about by the doing the simple things. We carried really hard and exploited a few gaps out wide.\"\n\nThe Wallabies face the All Blacks in Dunedin again next week and on this evidence their prospects of winning the remaining two Bledisloe Cup tests to reclaim the trophy for the first time since 2002 must be rated as extremely remote.\n\n\"It is not the start we would have hoped for,\" said Australia captain Michael Hooper.\n\n\"Being 50 points behind, you start to throw everything we had, I'm so happy with that.\"\n\nLooking to dispel some of the gloom hanging over the Australian game, the Wallabies put together some sharp phases positioned Folau on the outside and benefiting from a Beale spill to race away for the second.\n\nFlyhalf Beauden Barrett's neat short pass sent Crotty in for the fourth try and his centre partner running and winger Ben Smith giving the All Blacks a 54-6 lead after 48 minutes.\n\nFacing their biggest ever test defeat full in the face, the Wallabies rallied with the four unanswered tries to give the majority of the crowd of 54,846 something to cheer and secure a bonus point.\n\nThe All Blacks could have had a ninth try three minutes from time when Barrett, who kicked seven conversions, "Samu Kerevi"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samu_Kerevi", "type": "person", "id": "1273399"}], "body": "The Wallabies are hoping to shake a five-game losing streak against the All Blacks when they host the opening Bledisloe Cup game to kick off the 2017 Rugby Championship. Catch all the live scores, highlights and blog on The Roar from 8pm (AEST).\n\nThe Wallabies have won just a single game from their last 16 fixtures against their Trans-Tasman rivals, dating back to the 2011 Tri-Nations series.\n\nThe All Blacks have won 14 series in a row now in one of the most dominant streaks in sporting history.\n\nThe Wallabies, while Australian rugby is in the midst of a messy battle of Super Rugby sides, are fresh off a shaky June international window.\n\nA 23-point win over Fiji was a confidence-boosting start to the campaign, but they quickly began to tumble downhill with a scrappy and demoralising 19-24 loss at the hands of modern rivals, Scotland.\n\nThe Wallabies had a chance to recapture form leading into the current series, but a less than convincing performance against Italy only fueled the fire of Australia's rugby woes.\n\nFor the All Blacks, a monster 78-0 thumping of Samoa was the perfect lead up to the famed British and Irish Lions tour in June and July.\n\nAn incredibly tense series followed with a fired up Lions side stunning the home side with a drawn series thanks to an incredible 15-all tie in the third Test.\n\nThe defeat and draw in the last two games of the series leaves New Zealand winless across consecutive games for the first time in six years.\n\nAustralia will have to repeat history that hasn't been seen in nearly two decades to make it three non-wins in a row.\n\nWhile Australia's off-field and administrative dramas have been a coming in thick and fast, New Zealand have been no stranger to issues off the park in recent weeks as well.\n\nHalfback Aaron Smith's past has come back up to haunt his preparations, as well as veteran Jerome Kaino who was sent home the morning of Game 1 thanks to an affair scandal, being ruled out of the game.\n\nSince the 2015 Rugby Championship, the last time the Aussies toppled the men in black, New Zealand have won the World Cup, the last two Super Rugby titles and recaptured the Championship.\n\nTeam News\n\nCoach Michael Cheika has made a few notable alterations to his side following the undulating results of the June internationals.\n\nMost notably, Kurtley Beale returns to the Wallabies line up for the first time since the World Cup final in 2015, recovering from hamstring troubles that left him out of the side earlier in the year.\n\nHe will line up at inside centre alongside Foley in the halves and Samu Kerevi wearing the 13 jersey.\n\nOne surprise in the backline is the inclusion of rugby league convert Curtis Rona who will make his Wallaby debut out on the wing.\n\nIn the scrum, Ned Hanigan will lock into the back three alongside team mate and new skipper Michael Hooper, as well as the soon to be departed Sean McMahon at No. 8 before his venture to Japanese rugby.\n\nRetiring veteran Stephen Moore has held onto his starting spot at hooker.\n\nFor the kiwis, 22-year-old Damian McKenzie has been rewarded for back to back outstanding Super Rugby seasons with the starting fullback role after being left out of the entire Lions series. It will be just his third Test for the All Blacks.\n\nMcKenzie replaces an injured Jordie Barrett, with Ben Smith being shifted to the wing.\n\nHalves pairing Aaron Smith and Beauden Barrett are the only two to remain in the backline from the third Test against the Lions.\n\nAs well as the aforementioned McKenzie and Ben Smith moves, coach Steve Hansen has named Sonny Bill Williams and Ryan Crotty at inside and outside centre respectively.\n\nRieko Ioane takes flight on the opposite wing to Smith in his sixth Test in black.\n\nNothing too dramatic to speak of in the scrum with a very strong New Zealand pack shaping up.\n\nHowever, Jerome Kaino has sensationally been sent home following an alleged affair scandal, ruling him out of the contest.\n\nPrediction\n\nAs obvious as it sounds, this opening game is massively crucial, it's a must win for the Wallabies because they have all but no chance of winning Game 2 in Dunedin.\n\nThey're coming off a very nervy June campaign, coming up against an All Blacks side fired up from an immense series against the Lions.\n\nI don't think it will be the kind of blowout from Game 1 of last year in Sydney, but the All Blacks should Australia.\n\nThe stunning win followed the early departure of married All Black Jerome Kaino after explosive reports emerged he had an affair with an Australian model.\n\nAaron Smith (pictured) of Bledisloe Cup\n\nStar Kiwi halfback Aaron Smith showed no sign of stress on the field, running riot in the first half and flicking a perfect back pass to set up a try early in the second.\n\nHis composed performance followed a Daily Mail Australia report that revealed the truth behind his disabled toilet tryst with a lawyer who was not his girlfriend.\n\nThe contest was over at halftime with revealed by Daily Mail Australia showed the pair's affair had been going on for two years before the airport toilet cubicle incident, having met at a Dunedin gym.\n\nBut in the days after it became public the woman was hit by a flurry of vitriolic abuse online.\n\nDespite the seriousness of the threats the woman kept quiet, saying she feared ending the champion halfback's career and hurting the disabled toilet sex affair\n\nThe woman (pictured) claims Smith offered her money to lie about their affair under oath\n\nWhen she rejected his request to sign an affidavit denying the pair had ever "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rugby_World_Cup_statistics", "type": "wiki", "id": "1332459"}], "body": "A LATE Wallabies fightback helped narrow the margin but it couldn't prevent yet another Bledisloe Cup hammering at the hands of the All Blacks.\n\nThe Kiwis put a week of off-field scandal and distraction behind them to put the Aussies to the sword on it, scoring seven unanswered tries before 50 minutes had even ticked by on the clock.\n\nIt was the most points ever scored by the All Blacks against Australia but just as the record books were being prepared for a whole ugly re-write, the Wallabies staged a second-half fightback.\n\nLIVE BLOG: Re-live the carnage here!\n\nAustralia scored four tries in the final half-hour to narrow the margin from a record 48 points to a slightly more respectable 20.\n\nIt helped ease the Wallabies' blushes a little. But not much.\n\nFor as much spirit was shown in the last half-hour, the Wallabies defence oscillated between atrocious and missing in the first 50 minutes and any hope of victory was gone well before the belated comeback.\n\nThe Wallabies made 95 tackles but missed a whopping 48 in the game and at times the All Blacks appeared to be able to score at will.\n\nRyan Crotty and Rieko Ioane scored twice, feasting off Australian mistakes and defensive errors highlighting the disturbing lack of confidence in the Wallabies ranks this year.\n\nThe only defensive starch came in the last quarter, when the energy of the Wallabies bench helped them stave off an unwanted place in the record books.\n\nThe most points conceded in a Test is 61 against South Africa in 1997, and just one more Kiwi try would have equalled that.\n\nBut it didn't come.\n\nThe second-half tries also saw off the possibility of the 2017 Wallabies taking the record of worst losing margin (45 points) against the Springboks in 2008.\n\nTo be any chance of winning the Bledisloe Cup this year, Australia must now go to Dunedin to try and beat the Kiwis on home soil on Saturday.\n\nIf they play anything like they did in Sydney, that's not happening.\n\nWallabies captain Michael Hooper said he was happy with the fightback, but not much else,.\n\n\"I am really proud we showed that Australian spirit and came back there,\" he said post-match.\n\nAll Blacks captain Kieran Read said the game had felt \"surreal in the first half\".\n\n\"It's nice to play when it's all coming off like that,\" Read said.\n\n\"We tried to come here and play our game and a lot of cases it just stuck in the first half.\"\n\n\u200bIt would be easy to say it was all over by halftime, with the All Blacks leading 40-6 courtesy of six tries.\n\nIn fact, it was all over by the 25 minutes, when \u200bthe Kiwis used a 10-minute period to sink Australia with three quick tries and turn what had been a reasonably close game into another walkover.\n\nBernard Foley nailed a penalty in the third minute but the Wallabies' main problem -- utterly woeful defence -- didn't take long to emerge.\n\nAn innocuous All Blacks attacking line somehow managed to bamboozle the Aussies and Liam Squire raced down the left sideline to score in the seventh minute.\n\nStill, Australia continued to attack and an Israel Folau offload put the Wallabies in good position. They walked away with a penalty and at the 17th minute it was 7-6.\n\nThen, carnage.\n\nWhen the Kiwis attacked the Aussie line, they somehow turned a two-on-five into a try when Folau bit on a drifting Beauden Barrett and let Ioane score on his outside.\n\nThree minutes later, Ioane went in again when a rushed pass from Bernard Foley was knocked by Kurtley Beale and the Kiwis swooped on the loose ball to score. More simple missed tackles let Crotty score a too-simple try another three minutes later, and then, Australia were toast at 26-6, with 56 minutes of the game left to play.\n\nMore missed tackles led to the Wallabies defending their line again and when Sonny Bill Williams was given a short ball near the line, halfback Aaron Smith didn't even wait until he broken through two defenders to score before he hollered about the try. It was that certain.\n\nSamu Kerevi missed another tackle and Crotty strolled in for a disturbingly easy second try.\n\n\u200bIf Cheika's halftime speech made any impact, it didn't show.\n\nTwo minutes into the second period, Damien McKenzie scored a simple try while fans were still finding their seats after the break.\n\nFive minutes later, Ben Smith scored after more missed tackles.\n\nPeople reached for the record books to put context to the slaughter.\n\nBut then, suddenly, Australia's fightback began.\n\nCurtis Rona scored from a Nick Phipps pass in the 51st minute after a scrum on the Kiwi line, and minutes later Tevita Kuridrani scored a second when he took an offload from Folau.\n\nThe Wallabies scored a third in the 60th minute though Beale when he picked up a dropped Kiwi pass and raced 50 metres before Folau added try in the 67th minute.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531", "id": "10062321", "url": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Tew", "type": "person", "id": "497781"}], "body": "The All Blacks hit back after a horror week to smash the Wallabies in record-breaking style in last night's Bledisloe Cup test in Sydney.\n\nAfter a tumultuous week -- capped by veteran loose forward Jerome Kaino flying home just hours before kick-off to deal with a \"personal matter\" -- Kieran Read's men unleashed a destructive opening 48-minute blitz on the Wallabies to set up a 54-34 win.\n\nThe men in black rewrote the record books; scoring their most points in a test against the Aussies.\n\nThe All Blacks were up 26-6 after just 26 minutes, after tries to Rieko Ioane (two), Liam Squire and Ryan Crotty.\n\nA fifth first-half try -- to Sonny Bill Williams, who played on despite suffering a head knock that left him dazed in the opening minutes -- and then a second try to Crotty on the stroke of halftime helped the ABs to a dominant 40-6 lead at the break.\n\nThe pain continued shortly after the start of the second half, with Damian McKenzie, having a blinder, crossing in the 43rd minute. Ben Smith scored another try for the ABs, before the Aussies finally showed some fight and hit back with four tries.\n\nLast night's Bledisloe blow-out came after the most dramatic week in coach Steve Hansen's six-year tenure.\n\nMid-week the Aaron Smith sex scandal erupted again -- first with the publication of messages between him and his then-lover, then more claims by her in a series of interviews, and fresh claims about his off-field conduct.\n\nThe All Blacks then endured another off-field bombshell, this one on game day, after Kaino flew back to New Zealand after the publication of a story in Sydney's Daily Telegraph that claimed the two-time Rugby World Cup winner had had an extra-marital affair with a Canberra model.\n\nA statement issued by NZ Rugby said the married father of three -- who was not in the 23-strong squad named for the test -- had returned home to deal with a \"personal matter\".\n\nHis wife, Diana Kaino, wrote in a post to Facebook, which she later removed, that she was \"devastated\".\n\nNZR chief executive Steve Tew confirmed Kaino's unplanned return home about eight hours before kick-off, expressing concern about the development. \"We certainly understand that our game and our players are under public scrutiny and these latest stories are concerning.\n\n\"It is clear that this is really hurting rugby, all the people concerned, our fans and our supporters. We take these issues very seriously, and are also mindful that these issues affect people with families and loved ones.\n\n\"At a time when we are grappling with our cultural reputation, the Respect and Responsibility Review, which is under way, is even more important. The Review is being presented to the NZR Board this month and we are looking to make that public sometime in September.\"\n\nKaino's agent did not return a call for comment last night.\n\nTwo days before yesterday's allegations, NZR revealed it was reopening an investigation into the Smith sex scandal. An independent lawyer had been commissioned to carry it out.\n\nYesterday, the Weekend Herald published fresh claims about Smith's alleged off-field conduct.\n\n\"NZR cannot comment at this stage on what are both [the Smith and Kaino allegations] personal matters, but we feel for all of those affected,\" Tew's statement said.\n\nSmith started last night's test in Sydney. His long-time partner, Teagan Voykovich, travelled to Sydney last week to support him.\n\nSmith's agent did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMeanwhile, the Herald on Sunday understands a hard hitting 160-page document has been complied after a wide-ranging independent look at the culture of rugby. able to access to a maximum four tickets per person for the annual Test in Sydney.\n\nThat's right, tickets were restricted because it was so popular.\n\nTomorrow night only 50,000 tickets have been Vision courtesy Ten Eyewitness News.\n\nThis time last year, the Wallabies were blown off the park 42-8 in a match where they were unable to match the intensity of an All Blacks side with as much efficiency and skill of any side to tour Australia since the turn of the century.\n\nBookies are offering big odds for a Wallabies win and aside from a handful of diehard fans, few people are giving Michael Cheika's men any chance of upsetting Kieran Read and his mighty All Blacks team on what is tipped to be a windy evening in Homebush.\n\nRelated Articles Campese returning home and wants to save Australia rugby Super Rugby clubs call for ARU to show leadership in 'honest' meeting\n\nAustralia last held the Bledisloe Cup in 2002, have not beaten the All Blacks in their last five Tests and have only tasted glory once from their last 16 starts against the men in black.\n\nBut do you think Hooper cares? Not one bit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"What's wrong with a dream? What's wrong with a goal that everyone here wants to achieve? There's nothing wrong with it,\" Hooper said.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Rugbyheaven Newsletter Rugbyheaven Newsletter\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\n\"That's what we should be aspiring to and wanting. Everyone in our change room has that mentality [we can win]. This group hasn't been through the 10 or 12 or however many years. This group has come together this year to do something.\n\n\"This group is hungry and it is extremely excited by the challenge.\"\n\nOf the 15 Wallabies players who started in the Bledisloe Cup opener last year, only six are still there in the starting XV in what is largely a different side to the one that was smashed 12 months ago.\n\n\"We're completely focused on us and how we can get this new group, this new squad, in best possible shape for what is a very exciting year ahead,\" Hooper said. \"You can channel Super Rugby, you can channel us [losing last year], you can channel whatever you want. We are about building what we have started out in June this year. It's working hard together, building the bonds and building the trust and feeling confident in how we play the game.\"\n\nEven if the Wallabies are in the contest until the last 20 minutes, the All Blacks have shown in recent years their ability to put teams to the sword.\n\nHowever, Australia boasts 350 caps off the bench, headlined by the likes of Tatafu Polota-Nau, Sekope Kepu and Rob Simmons, compared to 169 Tests of experience on the New Zealand bench.\n\n\"They are really good at that 60-minute mark with that continued pressure,\" Hooper said. \"They know their roles really well and that's their bench included.\n\n\"Our bench hasn't seen the enthusiasm in the last couple of games that we probably would've liked to have seen, so we've picked a really strong bench. Lions and plan a big fix against the Wallabies, lock Brodie Retallick said Friday.\n\nThe usually rock-solid set piece was disrupted by the Lions in last month's drawn series, and Retallick said the Kiwi pack was determined to find a cure in Saturday's Rugby Championship opener in Sydney.\n\n\"I think we had our worst series in terms of lineouts that we\u00b4ve had in a number of years, so that\u00b4s obviously something that we've looked at this week,\" Retallick told reporters.\n\n\"There was a little bit of communication breakdown (against the Lions).\n\n\"We just didn\u00b4t know our roles, so it's been a huge focus of getting together and getting back to the standard we know we\u00b4re capable of, and our timing.\n\n\"As a forward pack we\u00b4ve got high expectations of ourselves to get the lineout right. It's certainly an area that's highly contested these days, so we\u00b4re always trying to put pressure on the opposition.\"\n\nRetallick, who forms one of rugby's most feared locking partnerships with Sam Whitelock, expects a tough battle with the Australian jumpers Adam Coleman and Rory Arnold.\n\n\"We have got some pretty tall timber and some athletes there, but in saying that the Australians have come a long way,\" he said.\n\nThe 64-cap Retallick said he was respectful of Coleman, who has emerged as the Wallabies' lineout leader in the past 12 months.\n\n\"In the lineout, and his "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Foley", "type": "person", "id": "1272251"}], "body": "SYDNEY: Rieko Ioane and Ryan Crotty both crossed twice as New Zealand ran in eight tries in a brilliant display of running rugby to demolish Australia 54-34 in the Rugby Championship opener on Saturday.\n\nThe world champions extinguished any chance of an upset with three tries in seven first-half minutes and sliced through the home defence almost at will in the opening 50 to start their title defence with a bonus-point win. Liam Squire, Sonny Bill Williams, Damian McKenzie and Ben Smith also scored tries as the All Blacks brushed off the disappointment of the drawn British and Irish Lions series and a string of off-field distractions.\n\nThe Wallabies scored tries through debutant winger Curtis Rona, replacement back Tevita Kuridrani, centre Kurtley Beale and fullback Israel Folau but they came in the second half once the game was already beyond them.\n\n\"It was pretty surreal that first half to be honest. We came here to play our game and it really came off. It was a pretty awesome first half,\" New Zealand captain Kieran Read said.\n\n\"It came about by the doing the simple things. We carried really hard and exploited a few gaps out wide.\"\n\nThe Wallabies face the All Blacks in Dunedin again next week and on this evidence their prospects of winning the remaining two Bledisloe Cup tests to reclaim the trophy for the first time since 2002 must be rated as extremely remote.\n\n\"It is not the start we would have hoped for,\" said Australia captain Michael Hooper.\n\n\"Being 50 points behind, you start to throw everything we had, I'm so happy with that.\"\n\nSHARP PHASES\n\nLooking to dispel some of the gloom hanging over the Australian game, the Wallabies put together some sharp phases with their first possession and were rewarded with flyhalf Bernard Foley's penalty in the third minute.\n\nFrom then on, however, it was one-way traffic in the first half with quick hands down the line sending Squire over in the 10th minute and the three-try burst from the 18th minute silencing what noise was coming from the home supporters.\n\nWinger Ioane scored the first two, beating a badly positioned Folau on the outside and benefiting from a Beale spill to race away for the second.\n\nFlyhalf Beauden Barrett's neat short pass sent Crotty in for the fourth try and his centre partner Williams, returning after a four-match ban for his red card in the Lions series, stormed across for the fifth.\n\nCrotty still had time before the interval to claim his second after more poor tackling in the Wallabies midfield to give the visitors a 40-6 lead at the break.\n\nIt was more of the same after the restart with fullback McKenzie, playing his third test, getting reward for his thrilling running and winger Ben Smith giving the All Blacks a 54-6 lead after 48 minutes.\n\nFacing their biggest ever test defeat full in the face, the Wallabies rallied with the four unanswered tries to give the majority of the crowd of 54,846 something to cheer and secure a bonus point.\n\nThe All Blacks could have had a ninth try three minutes from time when Barrett, who kicked seven conversions, charged down a Foley defensive kick, only for the video official to decide both players had grounded the ball simultaneously.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3370531",
