{"score": 5, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand", "label": {"eng": "New Zealand"}, "type": "loc", "id": "171", "location": {"label": {"eng": "New Zealand"}, "type": "country"}}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Chiefs (rugby union)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiefs_(rugby_union)", "type": "wiki", "id": "321202"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "British and Irish Lions"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_and_Irish_Lions", "type": "wiki", "id": "326436"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Steve Hansen"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Hansen", "type": "person", "id": "336058"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Forward pass"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_pass", "type": "wiki", "id": "345076"}, {"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New Zealand national rugby union team"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team", "type": "wiki", "id": "346371"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The Rugby Championship"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Rugby_Championship", "type": "wiki", "id": "350452"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Beauden Barrett"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauden_Barrett", "type": "person", "id": "350459"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Sonny Bill Williams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonny_Bill_Williams", "type": "person", "id": "356805"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Ryan Crotty"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Crotty", "type": "person", "id": "387145"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kieran Read"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kieran_Read", "type": "person", "id": "432870"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jerome Kaino"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Kaino", "type": "person", "id": "434172"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Owen Farrell"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owen_Farrell", "type": "person", "id": "513362"}, {"score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Owen Franks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owen_Franks", "type": "person", "id": "693211"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ewen McKenzie"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ewen_McKenzie", "type": "person", "id": "696406"}, {"score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Andy Farrell"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Farrell", "type": "person", "id": "769427"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Billy Vunipola"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Vunipola", "type": "person", "id": "852551"}, {"score": 2, "label": {"eng": "World XV"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_XV", "type": "wiki", "id": "942917"}, {"score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ardie Savea"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardie_Savea", "type": "person", "id": "1272533"}], "body": "A rush defence will not undo the All Blacks in the Rugby Championship - and it didn't for the Lions series.\n\nWell, that's a big statement so best start backing it up.\n\nMany a parallel has been drawn between the Andy Farrell rush defence and the series outcome but the match evidence suggests a confusion between causality and correlation.\n\nThe rush defence seen in the Crusader, Maori and Chiefs games, quite simply, did not exist in the three Tests.\n\nA quick summary.\n\nTest One\n\nThere will be zero disagreement Kiwi coach Steve Hansen picked apart the Farrell rush defence with ease. Clinical was the word I found most often used. The All Blacks attacked the narrow channels, won the gain-line with ease.\n\nRearrange the following in a sentence; barrel, shooting, fish - The rush defence provided no issues at all.\n\nTest Two\n\nI will admit assessing uneven variables is way past my pay grade, but a surprising outcome was that, even with a seven man pack for the best part of an hour, New Zealand still dominated possession, territory and all of the set piece stats.\n\nThe Lions forwards competed at the gain line for the first 20 minutes of this Test but that was largely it for any extended period in this series.\n\nNick Bishop showed that even with 14 men, the All Blacks were still creating space in the wider channels but not getting the ball there. Kieran Read got way too conservative for too long when down to 14.\n\nTest Three\n\nFor this game Hansen moved his point of attack wider of the ruck, as well attacking in close again, and with great success.\n\nNgani Laumape ran rampant, Owen Farrell missed five tackles and, for 50 minutes until Jerome Kaino went to the bin, the All Blacks made the gain line in close and went through the Lions backline almost at will.\n\nThe nine line breaks the All Blacks made this day would normally be enough to put a Test away but their execution was way below standard.\n\nArdie Savea dropped a sitter with the line open, Jordie Barrett threw a forward pass when Savea had an unopposed stroll. Laumape, Sam Cane and Barrett all spilled the ball in the red zone with the defensive line going backwards.\n\nThe execution was extremely poor, but it simply was not a function of any rush pattern.\n\nAdd Beauden Barrett's poor grubber kick for Read with the Lions backfield in disarray in Test two, and the execution errors really start to add up and get costly. This one, once again, not forced by any semblance of rushing defence.\n\nWhile the following clip's focus is on Beauden Barrett, there is enough in here to show that the All Blacks were in the back of the Lions almost at will.\n\nAny actual highlights clip of the Test demonstrates this at even greater length.\n\nSo why did the All Blacks not comfortably win the series and what will need to happen again to tip up the All Blacks in the Rugby Championship?\n\nHere are six things that made it the perfect storm for the All Blacks - almost literally.\n\n1. It rained - a lot\n\nLet's compare these games to New Zealand performances in wet weather Tests.\n\nWhile I am sure there are others, two spring to mind for me.\n\nvs Australia in Sydney 2014 - score 12-12\n\nI was at this game and it was miserable. A tight battle played on a soaked park in the rain and neither side managed to cross the chalk. Not sure I remember Ewen McKenzie being lauded for a magnificent defensive pattern despite New Zealand being kept try-less.\n\nvs South Africa at Twickenham, 2015. Score 20-18\n\nIf you are looking for the best rush defence executed against the All Blacks in recent years then go and watch this game. New Zealand scored two tries from five line breaks in an absolute soaking slugfest this night.\n\nFair to say, if you want to restrict the New Zealand attack then the weather gods will play a greater role in the outcome than any defensive system.\n\n2. A quite magnificent Lions scramble defence\n\nThis was the real key to staying in the games.\n\nWhether Gatland selected his pacy back three with this is mind is unknown, but this and the attitude displayed - Bishop calls it 'unity of purpose' - were the major contributors to the Lions defensive effort across Tests two and three.\n\nI have never seen a composite side with as much effort as we saw on this tour, they got up off the ground, covered each other, chased everything and never surrendered.\n\nJonathan Davies for me was brilliant in this regard, as well as timing his shooting out of the line in isolation superbly. The injuries to Billy Vunipola and Stuart Hogg that elevated Taulupe Faletau and Liam Williams ended up being fortunate bonuses to the Lions' defensive effort.\n\nRugby Videos See more \" Wallaroos register their first win of their World Cup campaign 1:05 Aaron Smith scandal leads to tense press conference 1:02 Justified red card or rugby gone soft? 0:58 Samu Kerevi itching to face SBW and All Blacks 0:59\n\n3. You don't want to play against 15 All Blacks all the time\n\nSelf-inflicted to a large degree, but the simple fact of the matter is there were 240 minutes of rugby in this series and New Zealand played with 14 men for 27 per cent of the time.\n\nYou aren't winning games or series being undermanned for a full quarter of the minutes, or more importantly, for more than 40 per cent of the last two Tests.\n\n4. Missing best in class players\n\nNot sure there is too much argument in declaring Dan Coles and Ben Smith as the best in their positions, while Ryan Crotty wouldn't be too far away if selecting a World XV. Coles remains out of Bledisloe One.\n\nIn isolation, this is something New Zealand should be able to cover, but in the perfect storm, it was a major contributing factor to the lack of execution.\n\n5. Goal kicking\n\nEvery New Zealander holds their breath every time Beauden Barrett stands over a goal kick. This was always going to cost a Test eventually and it very nearly cost a series.\n\nFarrell, on the other hand, was great in the clutch and confirmed himself as the world's best goal kicker.\n\n6. You need the rub of the refereeing green\n\nWithout relitigating the actual decisions, it would be fair to say the big calls favoured the Lions in the series.\n\nEver seen ten kickable penalties awarded in a Test without a yellow card?\n\nLet's say it, to tip up the All Blacks it really helps if Romain Garces somewhere in the immediate vicinity.\n\nIs it a coincidence that he was the appointment for the first Bledisloe Test before withdrawing through injury?\n\nAny single one of these items would normally be absorbed by what remains a quality New Zealand side, and to not lose the series against a very good Lions team in face of this perfect storm is actually quite impressive.\n\n(AAP Image/ David Rowland)\n\nThe series, however, threw up two interesting things you don't need to compete with the All Blacks.\n\nFirstly, you don't need to dominate the scoreboard. Over 240 minutes of rugby, the British and Irish Lions led for a sum total of three minutes.\n\nSecondly, you don't need parity in the forwards - something I'm surprised did not garner more comment or interest.\n\nWe were told the Lions would dominate set pieces, generate penalties, kick for touch and bully the All Blacks into submission, but nothing could have been further from the truth.\n\nThe Lions scrum, based on the Saracens model, was disappointing at best, toothless at worst. I'm not sure if Owen Franks has ever had an easier three weeks.\n\nNew Zealand scrummed at 100 per cent across the three Tests generating points from both penalties and try from this set piece. The Lions scrummed at 86 per cent.\n\nLineouts were really interesting. Across the series, New Zealand were at 81 per cent and the Lions 83 per cent, but there is a nice little quirk in the stats.\n\nOnce Maro Itoje was introduced in Tests two and three, New Zealand improved and the Lions deteriorated, with the numbers at 95 per cent versus 76 per cent.\n\nI would consider Itoje to be easily the best own ball jumper in world rugby right now, but it appears he was countered with relative ease.\n\nThe series is now consigned to history, and now the Championship starts, a wounded NZ, a revitalised South Africa, a super fit Australia and the ever mercurial Argentina. Bring it on.", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-3374401", "id": "9943897", "url": "http://www.theroar.com.au/2017/08/19/rush-defense-will-not-upset-blacks/", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "details": {}, "uri": "711569500", "extractedDates": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370531", "image": "http://cdn0.theroar.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Codie-Taylor-All-Blacks-New-Zealand-Rugby-Union-2017.jpg", "timeCrawl": "17:18:00", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:18:00Z", "lang": "eng", "title": "Why a rush defence will not upset the All Blacks", "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Programming/Software_Testing", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Programming/Software Testing", "id": 546}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "id": 823}], "time": "17:18:00", "source": {"uri": "theroar.com.au", "title": "The Roar", "id": "2423"}, "date": "2017-08-18", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18"}
{"eng-3370531": {"articles": {"page": 1, "totalResults": 263, "count": 1, "results": [{"id": "10132665", "categories": [{"id": 527, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 650, "label": "dmoz/Society/Disabled", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Disabled", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 651, "label": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Arts", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Arts", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 812, "label": "dmoz/Health/Mental Health/Disorders", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Mental_Health/Disorders", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1364, "label": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Travel", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Disabled/Travel", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712115793", "source": {"id": "5200", "title": "Scoop", "uri": "scoop.co.nz"}, "url": "http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK1708/S00487/ihc-new-zealand-pays-tribute-to-colin-meads.htm", "body": "Colin Meads - A man who made a difference\n\nMedia release\n\n20 August 2017\n\nIHC New Zealand wishes to pay tribute to Colin Meads.\n\nThe thoughts and best wishes of the many people associated with IHC New Zealand are with Verna and their family and friends at the passing of Colin Meads.\n\n\"While Colin is best known for rugby, to us he is one of a small number of distinguished IHC New Zealand Life Members recognised for their significant support for people with intellectual disabilities,\" says IHC Chief Executive Ralph Jones.\n\n\"Colin and Verna have always worked as a team in their dedication to IHC's cause and accordingly have made a huge difference to the lives of so many people with intellectual disabilities and their families.\"\n\nWe would like to share some of their involvement with IHC:\n\nColin Meads never stopped looking for ways to make life better for people with intellectual disabilities.\n\nIHC was privileged to have his support from 1974. He was a man who was generous with his name and his fame, driven by a strong belief that people with intellectual disabilities deserved the best. He believed that as a former All Black, with the opportunities he had been given, meant he had a responsibility to lend a hand where he could.\n\nThe legendary 'Pinetree' Meads played 133 matches for the All Blacks between 1957 and 1971. He was on IHC's team for 43 years.\n\nColin threw his weight behind IHC after he stopped playing rugby. In 1974 he was visited by IHC members - by the time they left, Colin had agreed to head up a newly formed King Country sub-branch.\n\n\"I said then I would give you two years. Within two years I was on the National Fundraising Committee,\" Colin said in his last interview with Community Moves. The two-year deadline came and went.\n\n\"We were going through the process of getting people away from the big institutions and out into the community,\" he says.\n\nHe often spoke about one young man from Kimberley Hospital in Levin, who became his friend. \"Dean Walker had been there since he was five.\" He was 15 or 16 when he left the institution to live in Te Kuiti and he became part of the community. \"It was the greatest move. Deano became part of the Waitete Rugby Club, so one thing led to another.\"\n\nColin put his money where his mouth was. Rugby in those days wasn't professional and there were rules around fees. So Colin and the IHC branch set up a special account into which he donated the proceeds from his many speaking engagements.\n\nIn 1988 this money went towards buying a farm in Te Kuiti for people with intellectual disabilities. The idea was to provide employment and teach farming skills and it became home to Dean and other men with disabilities for many years.\n\nHe remained concerned at the lack of employment opportunities for young people with disabilities and recalled the pride when someone got a job. \"I can remember the thrill of some of them getting their first pay. That was theirs; they were going to bank it.\"\n\nColin was knighted in 2001, but never used the title 'Sir' in his involvement with IHC. That would have set him apart. He was more comfortable kicking a ball around with a young disabled rugby player or standing for long hours at Mystery Creek Fieldays, whipping up support for IHC among his fellow farmers.\n\nColin was a natural fundraiser and backed a number of ingenious farm-based fundraising schemes. He bought a horse each year at the yearling sales, and he and IHC supporters sold raffle tickets and raised between $110,000 and $120,000 a horse. Colin also supported farmers Norm Cashmore and Mick Murphy who started the IHC Calf Scheme in 1983. They encouraged dairy farmers to raise a calf and donate the proceeds to IHC in exchange for a pair of gumboots.\n\nThe IHC Calf & Rural Scheme is still going 33 years later and it raises more than $1 million annually for people with disabilities.\n\nWhen Colin was made a distinguished companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit from Governor-General Dame Silvia Cartwright in 2001 he told us \"she said this is not just for your rugby, this is for your work with IHC also. I was quite proud of it to be honest\".\n\n\"Colin Meads made an extraordinary contribution to improve the lives of people with intellectual disabilities - one-on-one and on a large scale,\" says Ralph Jones.\n\n\"Colin and Verna Meads have truly made a difference.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T03:53:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 72, "textStart": 58, "date": "2017-08-20", "amb": false}], 757, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity/African", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712117607", "source": {"id": "2391", "title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "uri": "afp.com"}, "url": "https://www.afp.com/en/news/207/new-zealands-mighty-all-black-colin-pinetree-meads-dies-cancer", "body": "But it was Meads' humble persona, as much as his ferocity, that saw him lionised in his homeland.\n\nHe maintained a small sheep station throughout his career, epitomising the amateur-era All Black ideal of a grizzled farmer who could stride off the paddock and onto the rugby field to beat the best in the world.\n\n\"Colin Meads is probably the most iconic New Zealander I can think of,\" then Prime Minister John Key said in August 2016, when Meads revealed he had pancreatic cancer.\n\n\"He's a great man and the nation loves him dearly.\"\n\nMeads, nicknamed Pinetree because of his lanky 1.92 metre (6ft 3in) frame, was a one-club player, only ever representing his beloved King Country at provincial level.\n\nInternationally, he was part of the all-conquering All Blacks who won 17 consecutive Tests from 1965-69, a world-record feat only bettered by the team's 2016 edition almost 50 years later.\n\nHe played for the All Blacks 133 times, a number only exceeded by modern-day great Richie McCaw.\n\nMeads retired in 1971 after captaining the All Blacks against the British and Irish Lions.\n\nIn 1999, he was named New Zealand's Player of the Century and was later knighted, then inducted into the World Rugby Hall of Fame in 2014.\n\nHowever, Meads shied away from individual accolades and in his later years was happy to refer to McCaw as the greatest ever All Black\n\nNew Zealand Rugby chief executive Steve Tew called Meads \"a true legend of the game\".\n\n- Embarrassed by fame -\n\nHis reputation for toughness was enhanced when he broke an arm playing against Eastern Transvaal in 1970, going on to complete the game and finish on the winning side.\n\nHe then treated the injury himself using horse liniment, missing the first two Tests, but returning for the third and playing with his arm protected by a thin guard.\n\nThere was controversy, most notably when he ended the career of Australia's Ken Catchpole by pulling the halfback's leg in a ruck.\n\nMeads always maintained the incident was the result of poor timing, rather than malice.\n\nHe also became only the second All Black in history to be sent off when Irish referee Kevin Kelleher dismissed him for dangerous play during a 1967 win against Scotland.\n\nA myth developed that he shunned the gym and trained by running with a sheep tucked under each arm, although Meads insisted a photographer just happened to capture the moment he was carrying two sick animals back to the shed.\n\nAfter retiring, he continued to work his farm into his 70s before moving into the nearby township of Te Kuiti where he was ever ready to share his knowledge.\n\n\"If you come off the field and you feel you haven't done enough, you've let the side down,\" was a Meads maxim.\n\nOn comparing his amateur era to the modern professional game, he said: \"I used to sit in a corner. I didn't change until 30 minutes before the game. The haka was my warm-up.\n\n\"I worry about the modern game, I think they do too much warm-up. If you need tackling practice before the game, you shouldn't be in the team.\"\n\nAfter announcing in August (2016) that he had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer after feeling \"crook\" (sick) for six months, he asked for privacy as he fought the disease.\n\nMeads' biographer, the late Alex Veysey, said success never changed the big man.\n\n\"His rugby moved multitudes to wild-eyed, horse-throated frenzy,\" Veysey wrote.\n\n\"Yet when rugby day was done, he became what he had always been -- a farmer embarrassed by his fame, always seeking the quiet company of his fellows, a bit bemused when the autograph hunters besieged him beyond others.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T04:05:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 433, "textStart": 422, "date": "2016-08-", "amb": false}], "sim":
